https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114389,2023,Gezondheidsstrafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr.drs. L Postma', 'prof.mr. PAM Mevis', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

Het gezondheidsrecht is het functioneel rechtsgebied dat zich met de inrichting en het goed functioneren van de gezondheidszorg bezighoudt. Het is als zodanig van grote maatschappelijke waarde en betekenis. Voor dat goed functioneren van de gezondheidszorg wordt in toenemende mate en via een steeds groter wordende diversiteit van thema’s ook een beroep gedaan op het strafrecht. Veel wetten op het gebied van de gezondheidszorg (inzake medicijnengebruik, orgaandonatie, etc.) bevatten strafbepalingen. Voorts kan het begaan van strafbare feiten door werkers in de gezondheidszorg (BIG-geregistreerden) het vertrouwen in de gezondheidszorg aantasten. Niet voor niets bevatten de artikelen 96 en 96a Wet BIG eigen strafbare feiten ter voorkoming van de benadeling van de gezondheidszorg alsmede een eigen regeling om een werker in de gezondheidszorg uit het beroep te ontzetten. Belangrijker is de toenemende roep naar strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid (of ten minste onderzoek daarnaar) in geval er bij medische missers sprake is van een calamiteit in de zin van de WKKGz, hetgeen al snel ook het vermoeden van een strafbaar feit zal impliceren. Dan komt bij onderzoek al snel de vraag op naar de strafrechtelijke positie van de betrokkene/arts, al dan niet in verhouding tot de instelling (ziekenhuis als verdachte) en dan is ook het medisch beroepsgeheim en verschoningsrecht in het geding. In de strafvordering is het recht van de patiënt op onderzoek erkend als een dringende reden op basis waarvan het verschoningsrecht in het opsporingsonderzoek moet wijken. Dat verschoningsrecht staat sowieso onder druk. Zo onder andere in het bredere beleidsdossier tot het vergroten van de mogelijkheden om ‘ fraude in de zorg’ te bestrijden. Tegelijkertijd heeft het strafrecht ook zijn eigen uitgangspunten en structuur die de ‘functionaliteit’ van het rechtsgebied ook wel weer beperken. Ten slotte vergt gezondheidszorg in de typische setting van detentie ook enige bijzondere aandacht.

Twee terreinen kunnen nog in het bijzonder nader worden genoemd. Dat is in de eerste plaats het strafrecht en indringende vragen betreffende het begin en het einde van het leven. Zoals ook de media meer dan bekend, bestaat in Nederland een regeling waarbinnen uitsluitend de arts onder strikte voorwaarde euthanasie of hulp bij zelfdoding mag verrichten. Er is een aparte modaliteit voor levensbeëindiging van ernstig gehandicapte pasgeborenen. De hele regeling wordt via het strafrecht gecontroleerd. Alle maatschappelijke controverses verdienen ruim aandacht in dit vak. Voorts zijn met de civiele zorgwetten van de WvGGZ en de Wzd enerzijds en de Wet forensische zorg (Wfz) anderzijds flinke verwachtingen gewekt voor de adequate aansluiting van forensisch-strafrechtelijke en civiele geestelijke gezondheidszorg. Ook die aansluiting komt aan de orde.

De uitbreiding van de betekenis van het strafrecht wordt geïllustreerd door het feit dat binnen het OM een Expertisecentrum Medische Zaken (EMZ) is ingericht. Dat zal zich in voorkomende gevallen van strafrechtelijke rechtshandhaving ook over de verhouding met het medisch tuchtrecht moeten buigen.
Aan het einde van het vak kan de student zelfstandig:
-  De raakvlakken tussen het strafrecht en het gezondheidsrecht formuleren en waarderen.
- De typische strafbepalingen van de gezondheidszorg, zoals art. 96 Wet op de beroepen in de individuele gezondheidszorg (BIG) analyseren en becommentariëren.
- Het strafrecht als controlesysteem binnen de reguliere en alternatieve gezondheidszorg mede in verhouding tot de Wet kwaliteit, klachten en geschillen zorg (Wkkgz) becommentariëren.
- De wezenlijke samenhang van het strafrecht bij medisch handelen bij begin en einde van het leven formuleren en waarderen.
- De bijzondere positie van de arts als verschoningsgerechtigde, de gezondheidszorg in detentie en het ziekenhuis als rechtspersoon formuleren en waarderen.
- Een beargumenteerd standpunt formuleren met betrekking tot een stelling of casus over de rol van het strafrecht in de gezondheidszorg.

column1: Technological advances and global market expansion require marketers, advertisers and communicators to develop an understanding of the developments and factors influencing their field. An increasing number of Western companies are looking to compete in non-western markets as the saturated markets in their own country offer only limited opportunity for growth. In this course, students will explore how a variety of companies target customers in different cultures and how they attempt to make educated decisions with respect to research, strategy, media, implementation and evaluation in today's globalized marketplace. Students will analyze and reflect upon different approaches that companies are using to communicate with diverse audiences across the globe.

Drawing on various communication models, students will analyze and interpret current advertising messages and issues arising from the creation and distribution of such messages in other countries in  a variety of different media.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of global advertising;
• The environmental factors affecting global advertising, including the impact of culture, regulation, and competition;
• The variety of advertising strategies and tactics used in the international arena.
• Critically review current research on global advertising and its uses in the advertising world;
• Collaborate with peers in order to analyze, reflect and present real-life cases in global advertising.

column1: The ultimate challenges of global advertising are about preserving a balance between the culture of the brand and the culture of the consumers. In practice, many companies use standardized advertising strategies and tactics across the globe (i.e., use identical headlines and/or visuals in different countries). Although the practice of standardization reduces the costs of global advertising, it may also limit its appeal and effectiveness. Standardization, therefore, is highly debated in theory.

In the research workshop Global Advertising, students will first be familiarized with theoretical and empirical literature on the acceptance and use of standardized and localized advertising strategies around the world. Next, students join forces and design and conduct an online survey or experiment to gain an active understanding on the role of consumers’ perceived cultural similarity in global advertising effectiveness.

The research workshop Global Advertising enables students to gain hand-on experience in conducting and describing quantitative research. Two meetings are SPSS-sessions, actively guiding students through the data analysis and interpretation phase. Various sub assignments build up to the final product, which is a complete scientific report. Students get detailed feedback on the sub assignments, allowing them to improve their work.
Note: Working experience with SPSS is desirable, but not compulsory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• State-of the art theory on the subject of the workshop
• Common research designs and methods to examine the subject concerned
• Design and execute a small-scale empirical study
• Report on their findings in oral and written form
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research
• Evaluate their own work and others’ research work

column1: The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), ratified by world leaders in 2015, set out a framework to classify the most urgent social, economic and environmental challenges facing the world. The SDGs are a novel way of addressing an increasingly Volatile, Uncertain, Complex and Ambiguous (VUCA) world through a number of components that – together – constitute a new model of progress. Indeed, the SDGs are (i) inclusive, (ii)  based on positive change, (iii) defined as universal challenges, (iv) oriented to collective ambitions and (v) based on joint investment of energy and finance (as opposed to subsidies or philanthropy). The acceptance of the SDGs thereby signaled a badly needed ‘paradigm shift’ in contemporary thinking about conditions for sustainable development and the role(s) played by societal actors such as companies.

To reach the SDGs, companies play a vital role, as in some cases they are even more powerful than governments. This is a big change from the old mindset about sustainability in which development issues were considered to be ‘government territory’. In fact, companies are uniquely positioned to drive progress towards the 17 goals: among others, they have the ability to employ, invest, innovate and scale. This is especially true for Multinational Enterprises (MNEs), which are able to correct ‘market failures’ across borders by internalizing markets,  contributing to public and common goods provision and implementing practices internationally, and by their ability to innovate and scale.

We will consider the broader societal implications of MNE operations in both their home and host countries. MNEs are generally concerned with containing negative reputation effects that stem from their operations, and with developing a positive image resulting from the way they handle the manifold of societal issues in their firm and environment. We will analyze and formulate strategies through which MNEs can contribute to resolving the pressing societal issues defined in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) such as inequality, corruption, and climate change.
Attendance is highly recommended for all lectures, seminars and guest lectures. Attendance to a minimum of two out of the three seminars is mandatory. Attending Q&A sessions is optional.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Explain the (quasi-)internalization of international markets by MNEs
• Understand the institutional logic behind sustainability strategies in an international context
• Analyze why and how MNEs should address societal issues
• Formulate advice on sustainable global business strategies

column1: Global Challenges introduces you to several major societal challenges; many of which you will explore in more depth during subsequent courses throughout your degree. This course will give you an opportunity to explore how various facets of globalization impact the world we live in today.

The course is broadly divided in two parts. First, we sketch a broad story of how globalization has developed in the past few decades. During these weeks, we will talk about globalization and the nation state; whether globalization has changed the way countries deal with transnational conflicts; how institutions can help countries to coordinate their actions; and how the institutional system that has developed in the past few decades is increasingly under pressure by rising powers.

The next three weeks then explore globalization and global challenges from different angles or perspectives. We will look at globalization dynamics from the perspective of gender (exploring the complex relationships between gender and globalization), democracy (asking whether globalization and democracy go hand in hand) and environmentalism (focusing on environmental movements and activism).

Apart from exposing you to different ways of thinking about these challenges, the main goal of Global Challenges is to encourage you to engage in debate with each other. You will learn how to formulate your own argumentation, underpinned by real-world examples. No prior knowledge is assumed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course offers an introduction to globalization, and how it affects economic life in modern societies. At the end of the course, you should be able to:

column2: • Recognize globalization’s impact on culture and society
• Articulate the origins of international conflict and cooperation
• Comprehend the role of international coordination and global governance in dealing with global social challenges
• Compare various theoretical aspects of understanding globalization

column1: This course will introduce students to worldwide challenges in health and unhealthy behaviours, with a focus on low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). This will be combined with training to further improve students’ presentation skills and ability to provide effective peer-feedback.

We will set the scene by introducing students to the burden of disease across LMICs. We will identify the relative importance of communicable and non-communicable diseases and the “double burden of disease” these countries are increasingly facing. We will explore challenges in terms of treatment adherence and health behavior but also socioeconomic inequalities in health. To understand how health care systems can be strengthened to deal with these challenges, we will discuss financial access to health care and interventions to increase the demand of care including conditional cash transfers. This is followed by interventions to strengthen the supply side of health care systems including performance-based financing.
Throughout the course, students will learn to critically assess scientific studies about the above themes and will improve their presentation skills.
Note that this elective is also open for our own students Gezondheidswetenschappen (BMG). In total we allow max 30 students in this elective.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand worldwide challenges related to health, health care systems and health behaviors as well as policy interventions to reduce these, especially in low- and middle-income countries.
• Evaluate and critically reflect on a quantitative research method as applied in a scientific study on health, unhealthy behaviour and/or a related policy intervention.
• Present and provide feedback about a scientific study related to health, health care systems and/or behavior to peers.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113579,2023,Global Development Issues,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['A Krishnan, MSc', 'dr. CM Egger']",,"Inhoud

column1: What does “development” mean and how are global development targets defined and monitored? How do actors as diverse as China, Oxfam, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) or Mastercard work together? Why do poverty, exclusion, and vulnerability continue to destroy so much human potential after decades of development aid? What does Covid-19 tell us about the resilience of societies to disaster? Can we hope for sustainable futures in the context of climate change?

These are among the big questions at the heart of the Global Development Issues course. The course does not offer easy answers, but it challenges students to reflect critically on the key issues at the heart of the interdisciplinary field of development studies – namely, the improvement of the human condition. Delivered through eight lectures and eight interactive learning activities, the course introduces students to the concepts, ideas, academic debates, and policies that have shaped and continue to inform global development through an issue-based approach.

Structured around core development issues, lectures aim to highlight the role of ideas, intellectual currents, conflicting interpretations of history, and power relationships in shaping development processes and approaches to development. To discuss such core questions, the course draws upon knowledge and understanding acquired in global challenges, economics, organizations and management, political science, and international law. The course relies on the critical exploration of a varied sample of case studies allowing students to apply theoretical concepts to real life situations.

Besides gaining specialized knowledge and understanding, GDI allows students to apply skills developed in BA 1 and 2. During the course, students will develop an advocacy campaign based on the analysis of quantitative evidence (building on the quantitative methodology course) and a sound understanding of the ethical foundations of a specific international organization (building on the skills course). The best advocacy campaigns will receive an award from a panel of development practitioners on week 8. The simulation exercise scheduled in week 8 – possibly together with the International Migration course - will strengthen students’ negotiation skills.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Evaluate key concepts surrounding development theories and practices by drawing insights from sociology, economics, law and political science;

• Assess various development issues such as, development concepts and indicators, policy coordination, aid effectiveness, good governance, inequalities and poverty, inclusiveness, crisis resilience, sustainability and climate change via contemporary & historical approaches to development;
• Develop, with the help of others, an advocacy proposal that includes a small-scale quantitative analysis for an audience of policymakers;
• Compare the contributions and strategies of key development actors to development processes at a local, national and/or global level considering professional and ethical interests;
• Analyse how local, national and global development processes are interconnected using relevant cases and examples.

column1: <body>Global environmental dangers are seen by many as the greatest threat to the survival of humanity. How has this link between the environment and human society been constructed over time? What are the proposed solutions to this problem, and how have they been framed, debated, and contested? Giving historical perspective to the environmental issues we face today, this course will cover topics such as energy politics, global environmental governance, and advocacy politics. Focusing on contemporary history, we will discuss questions such as: What were the political implications of moving from coal to oil as energy sources and what consequences might a move to renewable energies entail? How has the relationship between the human and non-human world evolved and should non-humans have political representation? What role did advocacy politics play in the development of our current environmental governance structures and can green consumerism be an effective solution to climate change on a global scale? In doing so, the course will provide you with an understanding of the following three core themes: 1) how ideational and material factors have interacted to shape our understanding of the environment; 2) how individual actions and social structures inform environmental policy at the local and global levels, 3) how historical legacies of colonialism, race, gender, and economic inequality intersect to inform our current perspectives on global environmental politics.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - Students can explain and evaluate the main debates in the field of global environmental history
-Students can critically assess the relation between human society and nature, particularly as it intersects with legacies of colonialism, race, gender, and economic inequality
- Students can reflect on the limits and possibilities for political action</body>

column3: Global governance is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. The main purpose of this course is two-fold: to introduce students into state-of-the-art theorizing on the functioning of the global governance and to offer an overview of the most pertinent issues in global governance. The course applies the theories of international politics to the concept of global governance and relevant international relations; compliance with the international institutions; the rise of governance beyond the nation-state; interaction with domestic policy; and international NGOs.

column5: familiarizing students with the main theoretical outlooks in the field
presenting students with the most topical themes of the current global governance
enabling students to apply learnt theory in practical analytical work
teaching students to frame their arguments coherently and substantively
further honing students’ writing and speaking skills.

column1: <body>Please note that this course a part of Master International Public Management and Public Policy. Elective students from Master Public Administration tend to experience it as challenging. Furthermore, papers can be submitted only in English in all courses of this Master.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The assertion that global politics is undergoing dramatic change has become a truism. The objective of this course is to understand and contextualise that change. We will critically analyse whether institutions and practices developed during an era in which states were the dominant actors in world politics are able to cope with today’s myriad challenges. How does global politics work in an increasingly interdependent world? Are the institutions of diplomacy and multilateralism equipped to cope with 21st century challenges that are set to change the world profoundly?

The course engages with what has been described as the 'post-Western moment' in global politics. The Western-dominated global political order is increasingly being challenged by 'ising' actors, as well as new issues that are making their presence felt on the global stage: corporations, cities, individuals and other non-state entities.

Key questions that structure this course are centred on global governance: the structure problems that require a global political approach and the practices and structures that address them, the reality of which is rapidly and profoundly changing. Topics range from new forms and innovations in diplomacy as it relates to issues such as multilateralism, geo-economics, culture, security, and climate change</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114726,2023,Global Governance and its Discontents,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. L Green', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course deals with the emergence of Global Governance -and its discontents- in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. We will provide topics and themes that highlight human responses, reactions, and rejoinders towards the political processes of (global) institutionalizing and legalizing frameworks. We study transnational migrations; formal and informal intellectual and activist’s networks; and themes from popular culture like, sport, music and food that transcend national and international borders and shape identities beyond the ‘national’. The following twin notions will be dealt with: culture-identity, difference-equality, majority-minority, native-migrant, insiders-outsiders, hyperdiversity-uniformity; bottom-up-top down.

The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, where-after students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
- discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
- design of a research proposal
- one-to-one progress meetings with thesis advisor
- critical discussion of the research proposals
- discussion of and information on possible research methods
- discussion of case studies and other work in progress
- one-to-one progress meetings with thesis advisor
- discussion of case studies and other work in progress
- one-to-one progress meetings with thesis advisor
- presentation of the thesis research at master conference
- participation in discussions following presentations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115142,2023,Global Health Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['CF Parra Mujica', 'dr. IEJ Bonfrer', 'JAM Bom', 'MJ Mendoza Jimenez, MSc', ""prof.dr. OA O'Donnell""]",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), millions of people have no, or limited access to urgently needed health care. Universal access to essential health care is an important but elusive goal. Many low-income households are exposed to great financial risks related to  ill health, or are forced to forego essential treatments altogether. Universal health coverage (UHC) thus features high on the policy agenda and is one of the  targets of the Sustainable Development Goals to be reached by 2030.

Generally, to make progress on the path towards UHC, policy makers across LMICs are required to raise more money for health, to move away from direct payments at the point of use and to use resources for health more efficiently and equitably. This course aims to provide students with a better understanding of each of these three topics and furthermore to evaluate specific health care reforms on this path towards UHC. We also discuss the position and role of high income countries working in the field of Global Health in relation to attempts to “decolonize global health”.

The lectures mostly consist of case studies, presenting evidence on health coverage extensions across LMICs. While the course is not focused on teaching new quantitative methods, the sessions do emphasize how the effectiveness of UHC reforms can be evaluated quantitatively.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>By the end of this course, students should be able to

column2: • appraise key challenges that affect health systems in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) with regard to service delivery, the health workforce, governance, financing, medical products and technology, and information systems.
• discuss and contrast the burden of disease, social determinants and health inequalities within and between countries at different levels of economic development.
• distinguish the mandate, influence and interests of different actors in global health.
• assess and understand the rising burden of non-communicable diseases LMICs and evaluate its potential consequences on public health and access to healthcare.
• analyze the complexities of extending coverage of health care in LMICs. More specifically, analyze the limitations of tax financed health care.
• analyze difficulties in extending health coverage through voluntary health insurance.
• discuss innovative financing schemes of health care in LMICs. More specifically, outline the relations between provider payment mechanisms and universal health coverage.
• identify the scope for demand side interventions (vouchers, insurance, CCTs) in a specific context.
• critically assess the effectiveness of health care financing reforms in LMICs aimed at improving universal health coverage.
• evaluate the strength of the evidence base on the effectiveness of a health care financing reform.
• relate the characteristics of a particular health care financing scheme to the topics discussed in the lecture and critically assess.
• describe the economics of disease control and the global health challenges of antimicrobial resistance, pandemics and climate change.

• clearly present and critically discuss health care financing reforms and their evaluation to an audience of fellow students in the course. Analyze existing data related to health care financing in LMICs using the statistical software program STATA and interpret the output generated by this program.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114672,2023,Global History,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['BC Fici, MA', 'dr. S Bertrand', 'JA Seijbel, MSC MA', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

Global history is the story of interaction. Mankind has engaged in migration and trade since time immemorial. Over the centuries, the different continents, religions and nations have interacted with one another through the exchange of money, goods, information and world views. On the one hand, these contacts may lead to the fusion and mutual influencing of cultures; on the other, they also lead to clashes. Indeed, war, colonisation and decolonisation mark the boundaries of interaction and exchange. In these situations, people have a heightened awareness of what makes their own group ‘unique’. This is yet another age-old phenomenon.

In this series of lectures and tutorials students learn how to structure and periodize Global History into a number of major periods. Discussing these periods, the students become familiar with concepts such as mercantilism, European expansion, colonisation, decolonisation, the postcolonial world and globalisation. Throughout the course, we reflect on the major themes and key developments of human history. Using a variety of case studies and primary sources, the course establishes connections between global developments and their outcomes at the local level.

<body>Students are introduced to the history of the world from 1500 to the present. At the end of the course the students are able to reflect on periodization in global history. They use concepts such as Eurocentrism, colonization, capitalism, resistance, decolonization, post-colonial world and globalisation. Students learn searching and finding primary and secondary sources in the library and use them in a meaningful way in independently written essays.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114545,2023,Global Leadership,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. HGH van Dierendonck'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The contact between individuals and organizations from different countries, cultures, and social groups has never been greater than in our time. In recent decades organizations have continuously globalized their operations, resulting in increasing frequency with which employees interact with colleagues and customers from different cultural backgrounds and ethnicities. At the same time, as a result of legal, social and economic shifts, workforce participation rates of “traditional” minorities have dramatically grown, thus turning diversity into a strategic challenge in organizations. Further, as executives operate around broader regions, global teams are formed to address the need to become globally competitive, and customers and suppliers operate across borders, the demands on global executives are ever-growing.

This course is designed to help participants develop a deeper understanding of the issues that confront global managers today, and to prepare them for leadership roles in international organizations. Through business cases, experiential exercises, and real-life examples, the course strives to explore knowledge in leading diverse people as well as in leading global organizations. Emphasis will be placed on developing skills to manage diverse organizational units.

column1: Through drawing on both Global History and International Relations Theory this course explores the concept and history of global order from 1815 through to the present. Building on the themes and concepts established in The Origins of Global Order, this course centers on two of the 20th century major shifts: the transition from a world of formal empires to a world of formally independent sovereign states, and the transition towards a world dominated by - an increasingly contested - US American hegemony. We will explore how these specific constellations of order emerge and how their dominance is questioned, contested, and undermined. How do they develop and change over time, who are the actors and forces contributing to the rise and fall of specific order constellations? What are the different ideational, material and organizational elements of order holding them together?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Drawing on History and IR, students can conceptualise empire, sovereignty, hegemony and related concepts;
• Students can understand and explain how global order is formed, contested and transformed over time
• Students can analyse and compare different forms of global order
• Students can reflect and take position on scholarly opinions about key episodes of the history of power and global order from 1815 through to the present.

column2: • Content: This module will provide an introduction to the analysis of global poverty. column1: Global poverty remains the most pressing social problem of our era in spite of growing awareness that economic growth has been premised on forms of ecological depletion and social marginalization. Despite the fall in rates of extreme poverty over the past century, billions of people remain exposed to different forms of poverty. This minor provides students with tools to develop their concern for global poverty by introducing concepts, theories, trends and illuminating case studies on poverty and poverty-reduction interventions. Through lectures, workshops and small group tutorials students will develop a critical and global outlook on poverty. No prior knowledge of economics is required. This minor is coordinated by the ISS, a leading center for the study of international development.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: International, transnational and domestic actors shape and contest the global regulations and practices we live by. For example, the World Health Organization (WHO), which remains the primary organization involved in global health, provided guidance during the outbreak of Coronavirus. Moreover, the interaction between the WHO, development aid donors and pharmaceutical companies affects access of millions of people to affordable medicine by regulating production and sales of so-called ‘generic drugs’. Such interactions of states, international organisations, NGOs, private actors, legal norms and informal rules create international regimes – sets of written and unwritten rules that guide (but do not predetermine) behaviour in particular policy sectors. These regimes are not just legal rules but practical “ways to do things” on the global arena. Ultimately, international regulatory regimes are an attempt to bring order to anarchy, make sense out of complexity and establish rules and predictability in at least some global policy areas. However, the practice of implementing these global rules is often confusing and contradictory. For instance, anti-money-laundering legislation initiated by the G7 has found higher compliance rates in ‘developing countries’ than in OECD countries. In cases of high-level corruption, it is often NGOs and activist groups which elicit compliance, not the governments who signed anti-corruption legislation. These observations make one ask how we can achieve accountable and effective governance on global and local scales. Do the current rules governing global trade and related activities, including international cooperation in the health sector, provide for a common level playing field?

This course analyses the interaction -both formal and informal - between the different stakeholders (governments, business corporations, civil society representatives etc.) in the development and functioning of international regulations regimes that govern trade and health cooperation, affecting power relations across the globe. Amongst a variety of issues, students will address issues related to the production of generic medicine (TRIPS), fighting money-laundering and tax-evasion as well as bringing transparency to arms trade. By adopting this layout the course reflects on the systemic rules that govern global trade (food, medicine and health, military equipment) and shape our lives, connecting these rules with broader issues like inequality, human rights and political coercion.

Doing so, we challenge the simplistic assumption that global regulatory regimes always transfer most effective and best applicable practices that serve the 'common good'. By going beyond legal aspects, international economics and a focus on international organisations or state actors, this course provides an expansion to the POLIR and EUC curriculum. Students will explore practical issues of global politics in commerce and health to understand how implementation and compliance challenges power asymmetries and international arrangements on a daily basis.

column1: The course addresses the following topics on sustainable global supply chains: Supply chain risk management, supply chain network design, responsible supply chains and circular supply chains. The aim is to work towards an integration of the knowledge that students already have obtained in their studies with some new insights in global sustainable supply chains complexities and concepts. The learning approach as described above is very challenging because it requires the students to review and update their prior knowledge and study some new material as well. Therefore, it will be very important to prepare thoroughly for each class, by reading the required material and work on the assignments and cases. Each lecture, students should expect to give brief on the spot presentations on the lecture material in which they express an opinion and demonstrate their insights.

• Reflect on challenges and opportunities of circular supply chains using qualitative and quantitative methods

column1: Teamwork has long been a vital skill in the workplace. Today’s teams however are more dynamic and “virtual” than ever and are required to operate across disciplinary, temporal, cultural, linguistic, and geographical boundaries. Organizations increasingly rely on such global virtual teams (GVT’s) to participate in the global marketplace, to leverage talent globally, or to tackle global strategic challenges.

Unfortunately, getting global virtual teams to realize this potential is anything but trivial. Communication breakdowns, animosity and conflict across geographical sites, motivational issues, and missed targets are common. Have you mastered the skill of global virtual teamwork? Do you know how to help your team get the best out of its cross-boundary work?

This course aims to sensitize students to the opportunities and challenges of contemporary teamwork, with a focus on global and virtual teamwork. The course consists of a series of interactive lectures, including case studies, exercises, and group discussions, which will equip you with the theoretical knowledge and practical tools to gain insight into your real-life team challenges and deal with such challenges more effectively in the future. As part of the course, you will carry out a team assignment, which includes both content and process challenges within your team, which will (ideally) be comprised of members from different national backgrounds (and/or other diversity attributes), collaborating on their tasks remotely. Topics focus on the role of geographical distance, language differences, cultural diversity, and virtuality in teamwork effectiveness.

column1: Supply chain management (SCM) has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, due to current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. Supply chain management, as a natural successor to operations management, is a fundamental driver not only for further improving operations but also for strengthening the competitive position of firms. When a company faces the pressure of excessive inventories, degraded customer service, escalating costs and declining profits, or a poor return on assets, its supply chain is out of control. On the other hand, when a company moves into new markets or new technologies, it must have its supply chain prepared for new business challenges and opportunities. The course will introduce students to concepts and techniques related to the design, management and improvement of supply chains and supply chain operations.

The course focuses on a variety of challenging supply chain business situations.  For example, how different types of supply contracts can be used to design win-win solutions between buyer and supplier, how the benefits of information sharing can be estimated in the context of supply chain, and what supply chain strategies match with proliferating product variety. Other topics include, but are not limited to, inventory management, supply chain transportation and distribution network design, operational hedging and global supply chain risk management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of this course, you will:

column2: • be able to evaluate opportunities and challenges related to the operations and supply chain strategy of companies;
• be able to evaluate opportunities and challenges related to the management of supply chains in (inter)national contexts;
• be able to analyze performance-related business problems and design and propose solutions;
• be able to find relevant literature and apply this to a business case;
• be able to create feasible plans of action and develop sensible decisions on how to deal with a particular supply chain challenge;
• have knowledge of, and skills for, collaborating, managing and coordinating operations in diverse teams and in complex demand-supply networks;
• be able to defend problem formulations and solutions based on sound arguments; and
• be able to critically think about problem definitions and to reflect on solutions proposed by yourself and others.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114733,2023,Globalisation and the Making of Europe, 1850-present",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. JJ Euwe'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>After an introduction on trade before the industrial revolution, the relation between increased specialisation, industrialisation and the growth of economic contacts will be discussed. In the second half of the 19th century, monetary stability and free trade created a truly global economy, but not without suppressing a substantial part of the  world. From 1914 on, two world wars and the Cold War prevented a complete recovery of economic relations. Political interests caused that national economies were created with relatively limited international contacts. In post-1945 Europe this was a problem. Not only had the 1930s shown that economic nationalism was fatal for growth and development, but Germany also was a problem. For these reasons European economic integration seemed a solution. Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, this proved very successful. In the 1990s liberalisation of international markets, but also, just as in the late 19th century, an enormous decline of transport costs, caused a second period of globalisation. Now multinational companies cut apart their production chains,  and each step was done wherever in the world is cheapest. Europe was no longer the centre and its process of integration, that after the Cold War got a boost, is now even crumbling.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can describe the history of international economic relations since the 19th century

• Students can apply theories of international (economic) relations to historical cases
• Students can explain how developments in Europe’s political economy since the 19th century are related to globalization
• Students are able to assess Europe’s changing political-economical position in the world

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course starts with two general lectures on the question why we should be engaged with international and comparative research in criminology; how with the process of globalisation a so-called ‘global criminology’ has emerged; and point at some socio-historical and cultural factors that have determined why criminology developed differently in Europe, North America, Latin America and Africa. The key-question in this respect is whether concrete criminological questions can actually be addressed with theoretical models that pretend to have a global validity, but mostly have Western biases.

Next, we will follow the structure of Katja Franko her book, of which the central line is that globalisation and digitalization offers opportunities for certain people and indeed confronts others with new limitations and forms of social exclusion. Globalisation and digitalisation also come along with types of crime and crime control that take place across physical and digital borders. In this context, we focus on the rise of cybercrime and how big data and algorithms revolutionize ways to keep societies safe. Regarding the latter, we deal with the way police forces use big data tools to tackle crime and how tech companies take the lead in crime control within the context of smart cities worldwide.

Additional readings offer a more concrete analysis of each of these issues (including topics such as harm, eco-crime and crimes against humanity), whereas guest-lecturers and practitioners will bridge the academic and the practical dimensions of the issues discussed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course aims to give insight in the cultural embeddedness of criminological perspectives and research traditions; the different ways we do international and cross-cultural research in criminology in the global and digital modernity; the different themes in global and digital criminology; and indeed, the different positions that are taken in these fields.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114624,2023,Globalisation, culture and place",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TA Calkins III'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will discuss theories and empirical cases related to the contemporary functioning of art worlds and the dynamics of cultural globalisation and aesthetic appropriation which shape them. Arguably, cultural production and consumption have become more transnationally-oriented. We look at the changing relationship between cultural production and consumption and place; the networked nature of artistic production and consumption, and the social conventions that govern them. Students get acquainted with the major contemporary trends and developments in the visual arts, music and the media, drawing on case studies from Western and non-Western context.  This course will be conducted as seminar which foregrounds student discussion and analysis of the readings.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course aims to take a fresh look at the notion of art worlds and the socialized nature of artistic and cultural production and consumption à la Becker, in light of theories of and empirical research on cultural globalisation. Drawing on examples from contemporary art movements, the media and music industries from around the world, we look at how art worlds operate across spatial scales; and how trends and social conventions spread across the world; and how they become embedded in different places and social contexts.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114805,2023,Globalization and Media Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AFM Krijnen', 'FKS Robinson', 'L Kopitz, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Central to the seminar is cultural globalization: the global dispersion of (popular) cultural products. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows, thanks to much improved dissemination means (e.g. streaming and other digital technologies) and  transnationalisation in media and cultural-industry businesses.

Media are pivotal in this process of cultural globalization: all around the world, people are familiar with TV series such as The Big Bang Theory, the Marvel Cinematic Universe and popular music artists like Beyoncé. Globalization however, is not the same as Americanization: Indian movies, South Korean popular culture (K-wave) and formats such as The Voice are sold and consumed all over the world. In this course the meanings of developments in the media industries for production, content and consumption of media products is scrutinized. Due to their global presence entertainment genres form the focal point of this course. To critically examine cultural globalization in relation to media industries and the symbolic meanings produced the ‘critical political economy’ approach is adopted.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114031,2023,Globalization and Multidimensional Legal Orders,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. F Coman Kund', 'dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr. M Campo Comba, LLM', 'dr. M Markakis, MJur DPhil (Ox)', 'dr. M Stambulski', 'dr. OE Santamaria Echeverria, LL.M', 'mr. D Stankovic', 'prof.mr.dr.drs. JD Temperman']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During this course students will explore the multidimensional nature of the legal orders (a new development) that lawyers are confronted with in a globalized world. The focus will be on how various international and European Union legal orders, but also transnational legal orders (think e.g. of the Forest Stewardship Council wood certification scheme), inter-relate and how they relate to the values enshrined in national legal orders. The point of departure for the course will be how the internationalization and Europeanization of law relate to enhanced economic integration and interdependence (i.e. globalization) and may compromise values that are regarded as essential to law as developed in liberal legal orders. These essential values include those related to the rule of law, human rights and democracy. In other words, during the course, legal developments related to enhanced economic interdependence, often resulting in technocratic decision-making at international and European levels of decision making, will be problematized in an interdisciplinary context.

The course builds on the knowledge, insights and skills acquired during the course Research and Writing Skills (Block 1) in European Union, International Law and Global Governance (Block 2) and The Law and Policy of European Integration (Block 2) and in particular seeks to broaden the student’s knowledge of the processes already introduced in the previous courses and enhance his/her legal and research skills, both in writing and oral format.

The course is problem-based, in the sense that real-world issues/themes are the point of departure; it thus takes an inductive approach. That said, in considering these issues students will be prompted to master systemic critical analysis, integrating concepts which are essential components of the systems of International and European Union law.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students completing this course will be able to independently:

column2: • Describe, analyze and critically assess new developments in international and European Union law and the causes thereof;
• Describe, analyze and critically assess the consequences of a multidimensional legal order, integrating the findings of other disciplines, in particular political science, sociology and economics;

• Engage in legal comparison and integration, that is comparing and integrating legal developments at an international and EU level in relation to each other and to legal values associated with national legal orders; and as a consequence:
• Conduct systemic, horizontal and vertical legal analysis;
• Develop, conduct and account for academic research on issues pertaining to globalization and multidimensional legal orders.
• Develop and present different types of legal advice on pertinent legal problems (taking into account ethical considerations), both orally and writing.
• Constructively engage in peer review and reflect on their own learning process.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114836,2023,Globalization, Digitalization and Culture",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. MSSE Janssen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The so-called Islamic State recruits members from around the world for their cause through Twitter. Netflix recently declared that after analysing their browsing statistics, they realized that the old constructs of cultural taste in association with the usual suspects of gender, class and age are irrelevant in their algorithmic design. Solidarity marches are happening more frequently around the world –the Occupy movement, Women’s march, and March for Science. What these diverse phenomena are pointing out today is that we live in an increasingly global world where through social media, we are able to create new forms of communities, cultures and contexts that go beyond national borders.

Hence, it is worth asking: Is the notion of the nation state redundant? Does culture matter today in the age of the internet? As social networking sites and their impact spans across borders, are we living in a post-cultural age? To talk of global and representative practice, we need to expand our frames of reference, revisit sacred discourses and Western-biased rubrics of digital design and practice. A paradigm shift is needed in approaching cultural phenomena on the internet with a more global-oriented, open- ended and pluralistic perspective. This seminar investigates popular events, claims and trends by going into the history of dominant theories of influence over these decades including (post) structuralism, (post) modernism, (post) Marxism, feminism and (post)colonial discourse .This opens up critical discussions on key topics such as privacy/surveillance, labour/leisure, activism, democracy, and media consumption/production.  This is essential for students to be able to position their research and target audience within a more globally architected digital and cultural landscape.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Normative constructs in new media studies and dominant perspectives on digital cultures
• The development of key concepts on the globalization of the internet and persistent discourses on the digital divide
• The intellectual history and theoretical shifts in the framing of culture, community and technology
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods to their topic of choice
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form
• Design and write an essay; make an intellectually compelling argument on globalization of the internet and its relationship to culture

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114286,2023,Goederen- en Insolventierecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['BB Balla, LLM', 'M van den Heuvel', 'mr. A Schoneveld', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'RSM Bosch']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het goederenrecht vormt samen met het verbintenissenrecht een van de twee pijlers van het vermogensrecht. Iedereen heeft te maken met goederenrecht, of het nu de vraag betreft wie eigendom van een gestolen fiets heeft of de vraag aan welke eisen een bank moet voldoen wil zij bewerkstelligen dat zij een geldig pandrecht krijgt op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur. Het goederenrecht is daarnaast onlosmakelijk verbonden met het insolventierecht. Denk aan vragen als, moet de curator van de dief van bovengenoemde gestolen fiets deze fiets ook in faillissement teruggeven, of moet de fiets juist ten behoeve van de gezamenlijke schuldeisers worden verkocht? En mag de bank, die een geldig pandrecht op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur heeft verkregen, haar vordering in faillissement verrekenen? Dat en meer komt aan bod tijdens het vak goederen- en insolventierecht.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In dit vak komt zowel het goederenrecht als het insolventierecht aan de orde. Bij het B1-vak Inleiding privaatrecht is de basis van het goederenrecht in hoofdlijnen behandeld. In dit vak wordt dieper op het goederenrecht ingegaan en staan verhaal, zekerheid en insolventie centraal. Het vak heeft daarbij tot doel de studenten de hoofdregels van het goederen- en insolventierecht bij te brengen, zodat zij in de (commerciële) praktijk zelfstandig een goederen- of insolventierechtelijke casus kunnen oplossen. Vanwege het grote belang van dit leerstuk in de praktijk wordt extra diep ingegaan op het leerstuk van de verpanding van vorderingen.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Think about the last time you shared a link with your friends and family. It could have been an informative article, a silly meme, or a song you like. Now think again, why did you share it with your family? Most likely, you weren't the only one who shared it, but part of a viral spread of information. The Going Viral: Ideas that Spread Around the World course will help you answer that question. We will explore why some things go viral while others never gain traction. In doing so, we'll examine the very specific conditions that social networks set. The course will cover not only the positive potential of viral information spread, but also the dangers that exponential spread of misinformation poses to society.

The cornerstones of the course are set by three influential books on word-of-mouth. In addition to sections from these seminal books, influential scholarly articles on the topic are discussed. These articles cover the broad spectrum of academic research in marketing, from basic psychology to memory and attention effects in consumer research to quantitative modeling of social networks and information diffusion. So not only will this course help you understand and design successful ideas and products, it will also provide a broad introduction to the rich field of marketing research by covering one of its core topics: Word-of-mouth.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113025,2023,Good research practices: improving my research with open science.,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['A. Pires Ferreira'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the past couple of decades, the credibility of science has been questioned, with many studies not finding the same results when repeated. This included medical fields like cancer research where only 50% of studies were reproduced. This showed the need to make our science better: more reproducible, transparent, and open. These are the key principles of open science, an emerging field trying to improve our research. However, it can seem daunting to undertake the task of learning about open science by yourself. In this two-days course, we will introduce you to the why, how, and when of open science, with hands-on applications to practice open science in your own research.
1) Why open science can offer solutions to some of the challenges that arose during the history of science (e.g., low reproducibility) and its importance in society and academia.
2) How to make your science more open, transparent, reproducible, and diverse, across the research cycle: From the research question formation to the reporting of results.
3) The benefits and difficulties of open science, to help you identify when open science might be useful for you.

We will offer live lectures, interactive sessions, and practicals. This course is offered by the Rotterdam R.I.O.T. science club (https://www.riotsciencenl.com/), a grassroots initiative which promotes open science.

PhD students from the social and (bio)medical sciences, who are interested in learning about how to improve their research with open science. The course is tailored for individuals with little to no knowledge of open science.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column2: Understand what open science is, its principles, and history, as well as why it is instrumental in achieving higher quality, integrity, equity, and diversity in science.
Leverage open science practices and tools in your own research

column4: Why open science can improve my research
Forming informative research questions and hypotheses and preregistering them
Team meeting for Improving the transparency of my research
For support, contact Marjolein Barendse or Lisanne van Houtum
When to use open science in my research

column1: *the program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: <body>Our world is facing multiple complex, uncertain and value-laden problems – including international conflicts, migration, loss of biodiversity, and social injustices, to name a few. Such long-term processes of structural change addressing persistent societal problems are referred to as societal transitions or transformations, characterized by a multitude of actors (including but not limited to local and regional government bodies, social enterprises, multinational enterprises, and community organizations) seeking to influence them. This course focuses specifically on analyzing interactions between actors and identifying courses of action for actors seeking to actively explore, guide and accelerate ‘desirable’ societal dynamics, in the context of dwindling influence of Western dominated global institutions, the rise of non-governmental influence and anti-establishment social movements. As such, two guiding questions for this course are:

column2: • How can we analyze and make sense of ways in which actors interact in complex decision-making processes in which multiple complex, uncertain and value-laden problems are addressed; and
• How can the abovementioned decision-making processes be adequately governed?
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After following this course students will be able to

column2: • Define nature, causes and consequences of governance as a theoretical concept and as a national and international practice
• Explain how governance is rooted in [have emerged from] scientific fields such as political science, law, sociology and economics
• Explain conditions and impacts of various approaches towards governance;
• Analyze involvement of and interactions between different actors in specific complex, uncertain and value-laden decision-making processes.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Healthcare managers increasingly are confronted with changes in the policy environment affecting the ways they organize and manage daily care processes. For example, legal requirements for patient participation force healthcare managers to install patient representatives in their advisory boards, and safety regulations ask for structured ways of organizing and accounting for the quality of care within healthcare organizations. Policy measures also influence the strategic choices of managers; if patient safety is displayed as an important problem in healthcare, rendering patient safety a top priority of the healthcare institution can be a valuable way of presenting the institution to third-party payers and patients.

Yet, incorporating national policy aims and measures in the organization’s policies also transforms the role of the healthcare organization. A healthcare organization is not a neutral adaptor of national policy requirements, but actively gives shape to these policies. For instance, what patient participation means and how the actual role of patients in the healthcare organization’s decision making process is fleshed out in practice, gets shape in the day-to-day interactions between health care managers, healthcare practitioners and quality staff.

This course aims to provide HCM students with theoretical lenses as well as practical knowledge to the understanding and dealing with governance and strategy issues in healthcare organizations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students are able to evaluate contemporary challenges in healthcare governance, through a range of theoretical perspectives on governance:

column3: • Students are able to describe the concept of governance.
• Students are able to describe the concept of networks in governance theory.
•  Students are able to describe a shift from government to governance and the hollowing out of the state
• Students are able to analyze the interaction between institutional context and healthcare governance, through micro, meso, and macro level lenses.
• Students are able to describe the concepts of decentralization and neighborhood governance
• Students are able to evaluate practices of decentralization and neighborhood governance in terms of dilemmas and trade-offs

column2: • Students are able to evaluate contemporary challenges in healthcare governance, through a range of theoretical perspectives on negotiation:

column3: • Students are able to describe two different approaches to negotiation: bargaining and interest-based negotiation.
• Students are able to evaluate the possibilities and limitations of bargaining and interest-based approaches to negotiation.
• Students are able to evaluate their own actions and approach to negotiation in simulated situations.

column2: • Students are able to evaluate contemporary challenges in healthcare governance, through a range of theoretical perspectives on strategy:

column3: • Students are able to describe two different lenses on strategy formulation: strategy-as-design and strategy-as-practice.
• Students are able to describe the use of different strategic tools (SWOT, benchmarking, stakeholder mapping, PESTEL);
• Students are able to evaluate the strategic position and strategic options of a healthcare organization
• Students are able to create and present a strategic plan for a healthcare organization;

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114980,2023,Governance en regulering van digitale technologie,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr.mr. S Li', 'mr. C van Noortwijk', 'mr.dr. MY Schaub', 'prof.dr. K Heine']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is about the governance and regulation of digital technology. Digital technology is a broad concept, we will not cover all digital technologies that are available or upcoming. A selection is made. Examples of digital technologies that are considered in this course are: artificial intelligence and digital tools that are used in legal professions or that have legal relevance. In this course, two main questions related to governance of digital technology are addressed:
1)          why should digital technology be regulated? and

Both questions are approached from a critical perspective. For the first question this means we do not assume that it is per se needed to regulate (new) technologies with specific regulations. The question instigates a closer look at the challenges that are presented by certain digital technologies to society and to the existing legal framework. The first question therefor raises several sub-questions: what are the challenges that a particular digital technology causes to society? And can these challenges be adequately addressed by existing law, or is specific legislation needed?

Law can both facilitate and regulate digital technologies. When we look at how technology is regulated, the critical perspective entails that we asses if the relevant regulation can adequately address the challenges or problems that are caused by digital technologies. Can the regulation at hand -at least theoretically- live up to its aims? And: are there any follow up questions or new problems that arise because of the technology specific laws?

Governance and regulation of digital technology takes place on several levels. Global digital governance encompasses transnational and international (soft) law, rules, norms, institutions, and standards that shape the regulation related to the development and use of digital technologies. The legal framework that is considered in this course is international and (mainly) European. This course includes both public and private law perspectives.

Several topics that are relevant for the governance of digital technologies are expressly not covered in this course, because they are addressed in other courses of the Master program, this includes: ethics, fundamental rights, the protection of personal data, the legal status of non-personal data and data-security. These issues may be touched upon in this course, to indicate their relevance and their place in the bigger constellation that is relevant when considering governance and regulation of technology. However, these issues are not explored in depth.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students:
a. have an analytical understanding of the theory on governance and regulation of digital technologies;
b. can apply their theoretical knowledge on governance and regulation to different types of digital technology;
c. have general knowledge of the legal framework that is relevant for AI and software tools;
d. are able to adopt a critical attitude regarding the materials and legal framework that is taught in this course;
e. can discuss on an academic level with others concerning the subject matter of the course.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114119,2023,Governance in de zorg,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. KGM Fleetwood Bird', 'mr.dr. AGH Klaassen', 'mr.dr. AP den Exter', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak Governance in de zorg focust zich op de drie partijen in de zorg, de zorgaanbieder, de zorgverzekeraar en de patiënten(vereniging). Vanuit het rechtspersonenrecht wordt deze drie partijen nader belicht. Daarnaast maakt de student in het vak Governance in de zorg kennis met de zeer uiteenlopende relaties waarmee mensen aan deze zorgorganisaties verbonden (kunnen) zijn, variërend van hoogopgeleide, vrijgevestigde medisch specialisten tot uitzendkrachten werkzaam in de schoonmaak, van bestuurders, interne toezichtzichthouders tot leden van cliëntenraden en ondernemingsraden. Aandacht wordt besteed aan onder meer vraagstukken van governance, medezeggenschap en arbeidsrecht.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. De taken en bevoegdheden van de verschillende organen van zorgverzekeraars, zorginstellingen en patiëntenverenigingen (her)kennen, toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie. 2. De eisen van bestuurders en interne toezichthouders van zorgverzekeraars, zorginstellingen en patiëntenverenigingen en hun aansprakelijkheidsposities analyseren en waarderen. 3. De positie van van de medezeggenschapsraden (her)kennen en analyseren/evalueren wanneer en op welke wijze medezeggenschapsraden hun rechten kunnen aanwenden. 4. De regels voor beloning, jaarverslaggeving en groepsstructuren toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie. 5. De verschillen tussen het huidige en toekomstig recht (her)kennen, toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie. 6. De positie van de maat en de bevoegdheden (her)kennen en toepassen op een casuspositie en de aansprakelijkheidspositie analyseren en waarderen. 7. De positie van een medisch specialist (her)kennen en de specifieke regels toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie. 8. De rol van het Scheidsgerecht (her)kennen en zijn uitspraken toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie. 9. De regels voor mediation en de verschillende arbeidsrelaties in de zorg toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in op een casuspositie. 10. Een onderzoeksvraag formuleren en daarover een paper schrijven en de (voorlopige) onderzoeksresultaten daarvan presenteren.
