column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is coordinated by the Erasmus University Rotterdam and given jointly with University of Leiden, and Institute of Social Science, and is part of the Governance of Migration and Diversity Master programme.

This course offers a multidisciplinary outlook on governance of migration and diversity from the perspectives of public administration, history, sociology and development studies. The course aims to stimulate a dialogue between the practice of migration and diversity governance and a variety of theoretical perspectives on governance. During the seminars and site-visits the students are given the opportunity to engage in discussions with both scholars and practitioners of governance.

The course consists of seminars and field trips (or webinars). It includes two introductory lectures about the structure of the course and about the foundations of governance theory. The following eight sessions will be conducted by governance scholars working within disciplinary traditions of Public Administration, Sociology, History and Development Studies, each seminar introducing the topic and new aspects of governance theory will be followed up by a site visit to the organizations, where students are expected to engage in conversation with practitioners of governance.

The course consists of seminars and field trips (or webinars). It includes two introductory lectures about the structure of the course and about the foundations of governance theory. The following eight sessions will be conducted by governance scholars working within disciplinary traditions of Public Administration, Sociology, History and Development Studies, each seminar introducing the topic and new aspects of governance theory will be followed up by a site visit to the organizations, where students are expected to engage in conversation with practitioners of governance.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Based on the 6 lectures, obligatory and optional readings of the course, lecture slides and 4 theory-meets-practice webinars (or site-visits if possible) students at the end of this course will be able to:

column2: • Interpret various issues of governance of migration and diversity from different disciplinary perspectives (public administration, sociology, history and development studies)
• Apply these theories and perspectives to real-life cases of governance of migration and diversity
• Formulate recommendations to governance actors to improve their governance practice (grounded in real-life cases, based on scientific evidence and theoretical perspectives)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Cities are increasingly seen as important places to ‘govern’ health. In the Netherlands, cities have gained more responsibilities since the decentralizations of care and support to local municipalities. On the local level, solutions need to be found for pressing problems, such as rising health inequalities between neighbourhoods, fragmented public service provision, and unsuitable housing for aging populations. To address these problems in innovative ways, experiments are being conducted in urban labs and inter-sectoral networks are set-up to enhance collaboration between different stakeholders in the city.

In this course we explore the ways in which urban health has come to be governed in modern societies. Governance, in the literature as well as in practices, stands for policy without central policy actors. That is: policymaking and implementation have come to rest on a myriad of actors and perspectives that are interwoven in networks. The course therefore serves as a guide to how urban governance for health is being done. This will be discussed both on a theoretical level (using concepts) and on practical level (using urban action research).

During the course students will work together with a field partner in Rotterdam on a specific urban issue. This ‘action-research’ will allow students to delve deeper into an urban problem and propose policy recommendations for solving it. Grading is based on a group paper, where theoretical concepts and recommendations for practice come together, and on an individual open-questions exam.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective of this course is for students to get acquainted with healthcare governance as a concept and the different shapes and forms of governance in practice. More specifically, the following learning goals apply to this course:

column2: • Students have an understanding of the shift from government to governance
• Students have an understanding of different coordination modes in governance (market, state, networks and communities)
• Students can explain the connection between place and healthcare governance.
• Students can apply theoretical concepts from the literature to analyze empirical cases of healthcare governance (see the 2 cases in Feijenoord, Rotterdam)
• Students will be able to develop useful policy recommendations for Feijenoord on the basis of the key concepts and themes of this course
• Students are able to explain and critically reflect on how people can be ‘responsibilized’ and be ‘made governable’
• Students are able to effectively discuss literature and issues on governance during meetings
• Students are able to provide peer-support to each other during workgroups by reading and discussing each other’s draft version of the report
• Students are able to write a coherent essay on the basis of a clear research question.

On the local level, solutions need to be found for pressing problems, such as rising health inequalities between neighbourhoods, fragmented public service provision, and unsuitable housing for aging populations. By following this course, students will develop an in-depth understanding of the possibilities and difficulties of governing healthy cities.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110688,2023,Governing Social Inequalities in the 21st century,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. BE French', 'dr. G Mari']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course examines social inequalities and related policy and institutional responses in three key arenas of 21st century contention. We focus on three axes of social inequality and related arenas of policymaking: class and redistribution, race and racism, place and the climate crisis. Each of these three arenas presents momentous challenges for communities and policymakers worldwide. Through a selection of case studies, the key aim of the course is to provide students with a toolkit to evaluate how policies and institutions can produce, maintain, mitigate, or exacerbate social inequalities. Examples of the topics covered in the course are basic income policies, affirmative action in higher education, and policy responses to natural disasters.

Special attention is devoted to the historical legacy of policies and institutions, their current design, their (unintended) consequences for individuals and households, and trade-offs between different policy instruments, objectives, and results. The course exposes students to interdisciplinary research in the relevant fields. Course participation and discussion is highly encouraged and instrumental to the course success.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Review and analyse theory- and evidence-based accounts of the features and consequences of different policies and institutions, with a particular emphasis on the (re)production of social inequalities;
2. Reflect on path dependence in policies and institutions and how their evolution co-occurs together with socio-economic, demographic, and political developments;

3. Identify trade-offs and unintended consequences of policies and institutional arrangements, e.g. how policies and institutions might mitigate some social inequalities while simultaneously producing or intensifying others;
4. Systematize and apply insights from sociology and other social sciences to analyse policies/institutions and their consequences.
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skills:
1. Critically assess theories and empirical evidence in scholarly debates around policies and institutions;
2. Make informed policy recommendations and contributions to the public debate, especially in the realm of policies and institutions implicated in social inequalities;
3. Report and summarise findings in a clear and effective manner (in writing).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110731,2023,Governing Urban Economic Growth and Innovation,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. J Fransen', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Cities are dynamic engines of economies growth and innovation, but they also create negative externalities such as inequality, poverty and pollution. As a result, new approaches have come up to work towards a more sustainable and inclusive economy. Urban economies are primarily coordinated by market transactions, many of which take place at an (inter)national level. The ability of urban governments to influence markets is limited and widely discussed. The course adopts a network governance perspective, debating if and how varying combinations of markets, state and non-state actors steer and facilitate towards sustainable urban economic development. The question is if and how urban network governance can stimulate economic innovation in a sustainable direction.

The course first discusses multi-disciplinary factors driving economic growth, creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship in a global economy. Subsequently the section zooms in on transitions towards sustainable and resilient urban economies, responding to recent challenges such as climate change, financial crises and growing inequality.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students are able to:
1. Distinguish and apply different perspectives to urban economic governance
2. Analyze the complex nature of urban economic governance across and within sectors and cities
3. Formulate conditions for sustainable and inclusive urban economic growth and inclusive innovation
4. Determinate strategies to overcome negative externalities (like poverty, inequality and pollution)</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111877,2023,Governing just sustainability transitions,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JM Wittmayer', 'prof.dr. A Kalfagianni']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Our world is facing multiple complex, uncertain and value-laden problems – including climate change, social injustices, loss of biodiversity to name a few of the most pressing one. To address such problems, our societies need to change in structural and profound ways. Structural change – taking place over a long-term horizon – aiming at addressing persistent societal problems are referred to as societal transitions or transformations. Considering the emergent nature of societal transitions and their dynamics – the future remains plural and uncertain with many actors seeking to influence and govern them. One may think about, among others, (transnational) social movements such as Extinction Rebellion; local, regional, and national governments, international organisations, non-governmental actors, but also big business and social enterprises, next to community groups. This course focuses specifically on the normative ideals of sustainability and justice as guiding ideas for actors seeking to actively explore, guide and accelerate ‘desirable’ societal dynamics.

This course seeks to help students understand how actors make sense of this context of global destabilization and prepare for desirable futures. The two main questions tackled in the course are: (i) how can we make sense of/understand discourses and actions around just sustainability transitions and competing discourses, and (ii) to what extent and how can just sustainability transitions be governed? You will learn how you can contribute to debates about just sustainability transitions considering different perspectives and how you can design a transition governance intervention. The governance of transitions arises from the agency of a diversity of actors involved in structural change and innovative action and their attempts to orchestrate the changes taking place at different levels. Hence, the keywords in this regard are scenario building, experimentation, learning, and reflexivity.

The teaching methods comprise lectures, classroom discussions and exercises, as well as individual and group work. The lectures and discussions are intended to give you a grounding in transition thinking, while the group work will allow you to design a transition governance intervention. The written examination will then focus on the lecture material on just sustainability transitions and their governance, whilst in the group work presentation students share the results of their group work.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114048,2023,Government and Business,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. SF Airey', 'mr.dr. P Jansen', 'prof.dr. LS Reins', 'Y Liu']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course examines regulation in all its variants, locating it alongside other approaches to governance. More than in a traditional public law programme, as a student you will engage with thinking from disciplines beyond law and public administration to analyse the drivers of different approaches to the governance of markets and technologies  and relevant actors.

Conceptually, a distinction can always be made between the goal, the way to achieve that goal and the question of how one starting point /set of rules may conflict with another starting point / other set of rules. However, in this course, we extend this approach further to include in-depth consideration of important contextual factors that shape regulatory decision-making, choice of governance instrument, and governance practice. These include for example the timing of regulatory intervention, regulatory principles or the regulation of new technologies and innovation.

This course is structured in two modules. Module 1 explores different approaches to the analysis of governance of markets modalities, drawing from legal, political economy, and historical perspectives. Module 2 focuses on specific case studies to demonstrate legal issues that arise when different modes of governance are applied. Together, these modules engage with pressing issues on evolving approaches to the governance and regulation of business and markets. These include shifts in public and private authority, identity, instruments, and modalities of regulation and governance of markets. They also engage with emergent thinking on new challenges to and modalities of democratic accountability, legitimacy and responsibility.

On completion of this course, participants will be familiar with the variety of approaches by government to the governance and regulation of business and markets, including but also beyond that of public law approaches. They will understand and be able to critically analyse new and emerging developments in approaches to governance of markets and technologies including the roles of private self-regulation, disruptive technologies, innovation, competition and investment, while thoughtfully engaging with questions of legitimacy, accountability, balancing of public and private interests, and the nature of the public good.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>At the end of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Have an advanced and integrated understanding of the complex body of knowledge on modalities of governance and regulation of business and markets
• Be able to analyze, critically reflect on and synthesize complex information, concepts and theories on the governance and regulation of business and markets
• Research and apply this knowledge to current problems and circumstances, and demonstrate autonomy, expert judgment, adaptability and responsibility as a graduate learner
• Interpret and communicate this knowledge, skills and ideas to specialist and non-specialist audiences

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116418,2023,Graduation Project,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. R van den Akker', 'MI Labarca Hoyl', 'OT Bream McIntosh']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the graduation project students work in transdisciplinary project teams to create a transformative intervention with and for a societal partner. The students research the persistent problems and transition dynamics based on existing academic literature and other forms of documentation, interviews and workshops, to develop a transition strategy and -intervention in co-creation with stakeholders and/or a societal partner. The graduation project consists of a preparatory phase and 3 (non-lineair, iterative) main phases.

column2: • Phase 0. Prejection (Preparation): Students select a topic with and for a societal partner within the context of a societal transition. They can build upon the work they did in the courses but can also choose a new topic, as long as it presents a complex societal challenge and the transition intervention has practical and tangible implications. They develop a proposal in which they introduce their societal challenge, topic, and plan of action, including productive interactions with each other and stakeholders.

• Phase 1: Exploration and framing (co-define and co-determine): Students explore and frame a specific transition challenge, the potentials for radical transition, and an intervention that can support radical transition.
• Phase 2: Design and action (co-design and co-create): Students design and organize an intervention.
• Phase 3: Evaluation and presentation (making public): Students produce a written evaluation and public presentation of the strengths, vulnerabilities and uncertainties of a transition intervention.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After this graduation project students are able situate themselves (i.e. based on experiences, skills, knowledges) in relation to societal stakeholders, -challenges, and -transitions. They are able to do so by applying the four core competencies of the Master Societal Transitions: Think, Connect, Act, Reflect. In this manner, this graduation project enables students to:

column2: • co-define a transition approach with and for a societal partner from a multi-actor perspective;
• co-determine the scale and scope of transformative agency from a multi-level perspective in order to engage with a complex societal issue.
• co-design and co-create an intervention with and for a societal partners;
• Evaluate and make public the strengths, vulnerabilities and uncertainties of their intervention;
• Reflect on their situatedness in relation to a complex societal concern, group dynamics and agency.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Handelingen en gedragingen als misdaad kwalificeren en bestraffen, is geen theorieloze en eeuwig onveranderlijke praktijk. Aan dit gebeuren liggen talrijke filosofische en politieke vooronderstellingen ten grondslag die evolueren in de tijd. Over deze theoretische vooronderstellingen en achterliggende historische denkkaders, wordt in het vak grondslagen van de criminologie gereflecteerd.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Inzicht verschaffen in de maatschappelijke verhoudingen en filosofische opvattingen die een rol hebben gespeeld bij de historische ontwikkeling van de ideeën over misdaad en straf.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de vraag waarom in bepaalde historische periodes gewetensdelicten zoals ketterij strafwaardig geacht werden en hoe men reageerde op een verdenking van hekserij.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol die de godsdienst speelde in de vervolging van gewetensdelicten en hekserij.

• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag waarom een staat het recht heeft om diegenen die afwijken van bepaalde normen te straffen en inzicht verschaffen in de wijze waarop dit filosofisch gerechtvaardigd wordt?
• Studenten kritisch leren reflecteren over de reikwijdte van overheidsmacht en over de filosofische oorsprong en de grondslag van individuele rechten tegenover de staat.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol en de betekenis van de Verlichtingsfilosofie in dit proces.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat tussen utilisten en retributivisten in de strafrechtsfilosofie.
• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag of (en zo ja hoe) foltering en de doodstraf kunnen gerechtvaardigd worden (en indien niet, waarom?)
• Inzicht verschaffen in de verschillende ethische theorieën die een antwoord formuleren op de vraag wanneer de overheid iets strafrechtelijk mag verbieden?
• Studenten kritisch doen nadenken over de vraag of alleen individuen misdaden kunnen plegen dan wel of ook staten en (internationale) organisaties dat doen?
• Studenten doen reflecteren over de vraag of het object van de criminologie ruimer is dan louter datgene wat door de strafwetgever strafbaar is gesteld.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met de manier waarop de criminologie als wetenschap is ontstaan en hoe zij zich verhoudt tot de (totalitaire) politiek.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat over vrije wil en determinisme in de strafrechtstheorie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: It is no coincidence that our psychology bachelor curriculum in Rotterdam begins with a course about people in groups (social psychology). Groups were central to the human past, are central to our present, and will continue to be central to the human future. To understand human behavior, we need to understand groups, because people live in groups, play in groups, and.... work and perform in groups.

As a Work and Organizational Psychologist, you will be faced with groups at work all the time: departments, project teams, discussion groups, boards, work teams, et cetera. Often, your involvement will be about improving groups and teams, about suggesting or implementing changes to make them more effective. In your future job you may, for example, design groups, build groups (or teams), advise groups, train groups, disband groups, address groups, motivate groups, study groups, or simply participate in groups.

By providing hands-on insight in and experience with state-of-the-art topics in the domain of groups at work, this course aims to prepare you for these and other intriguing encounters with the practice of groups at work.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course aims to help students gain insight in scientific research on working in groups and teams. The focus is on analyzing, evaluating, and integrating scientific information in close collaboration with others with the purpose of designing evidence-based answers to academic or organizational questions, while also developing your own teamwork skills and insights.
Upon successful completion of this course, you:

column2: • have gained insight into teamwork theory and research. can interpret and critically evaluate the results of team research, considering a study’s theory, design, and methodology.
• are better able to integrate results and conclusions across different studies to evaluate their combined implications for the relevant content area.
• can collaborate with others to design a collective evidence-based answer to applied academic or practical questions/problems.
• have developed key teamwork competencies and gained experience in recognizing behaviors and processes that facilitate or hinder effective team functioning.

column1: The Guidance course consists of 5 tutorials in block 1 and study progress meetings in block 2 and 3. Each Guidance group consists of max. 15 students and one mentor (a senior student). In addition, three individual meetings will take place where you can discuss any issues, questions, or your study results with the mentor. You can always reach out to your mentor for help or if you have questions.

The Guidance course will allow you to get to know your fellow students. In the tutorials your mentor will help you get a smooth start with your studies. You will discuss study skills, what it means to be part of the academic community, and you will reflect on your own goals and learning process.
At the end of this course you …

column2: • have gotten to know the EUR, ESE, your mentor and your classmates. You have become acquainted with the Erasmian values and what it means to be an ESE student. You know about the expectations ESE has for an inclusive and safe learning environment and your role in this.

• can apply effective studying methods and have reflected on several learning techniques. You also know how to use the online study environment, you know where to find the general rules and regulations about the BSA, attendance, and exam regulations and preparation.
• you understand why plagiarism and fraud is not allowed and you know that you are now part of the academic community and have an academic integrity code to uphold.
• you understand you are responsible for your own learning journey, and you are prepared to take on that responsibility.
• you know where to turn to for help for yourself or other students. You know how to access resources for counselling and advice. You are aware of the existence of confidential counsellors.

column1: At the end of this course you …

column2: • have gotten to know the EUR, ESE, your mentor and your classmates. You have become acquainted with the Erasmian values and what it means to be an ESE student. You know about the expectations ESE has for an inclusive and safe learning environment and your role in this.

• can apply effective studying methods and have reflected on several learning techniques. You also know how to use the online study environment, you know where to find the general rules and regulations about the BSA, attendance, and exam regulations and preparation.
• you understand why plagiarism and fraud is not allowed and you know that you are now part of the academic community and have an academic integrity code to uphold.
• you understand you are responsible for your own learning journey, and you are prepared to take on that responsibility.
• you know where to turn to for help for yourself or other students. You know how to access resources for counselling and advice. You are aware of the existence of confidential counsellors.

column1: Human Resources have increasingly been recognised as a source of competitive advantage and as such good people management is vital for organisations. The course is designed to develop a thorough knowledge and understanding of the effective management of people. After exploring the theoretical origins of HRM, the emergence of HR strategy and the relationship between business strategy and HRM strategy, the course will focus on discussing and analysing important HRM activities such as HR planning, recruitment and selection, training and development, absence and retention management, reward and performance and exit management. A deepened understanding of the strategic character of these practical HRM activities provides students with the knowledge and skills required for the integration of HR policies into a coherent HRM strategy, the implementation of which will contribute to a high-performance organisation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Syrian civil war, the Ebola epidemic, Covid-19, hurricane Katrina, the Rohingya crisis, the earthquakes in Nepal and Haiti, the Japanese tsunami, the Indian Ocean tsunami, the HIV/AIDS epidemic,… the world has experienced many large humanitarian crises in past decades. Climate change, population growth, and rapid urbanization will likely only increase their frequency and impact in the future. At the same time, the world is still facing several substantial development challenges. For example, nearly 2 billion people still lack access to basic medicines and more than half the world population still lacks access to essential health services.

These health and humanitarian crises come with extreme demands for logistics, technology, and operations management. Extreme in terms of operating conditions. Extreme due to the scarcity of resources. And extreme in terms of consequences for health and well-being. For example, managing disaster response is like organizing the next Olympic Games without knowing where it will take place, when it will take place, and how many people will come. Though this seems pretty impossible, the way response is being prepared and managed is a matter of life and death for many. Similarly, increasing access to medicines and health services in low and middle income countries is about addressing a disproportionally heavy burden of disease with very limited resources (doctors, clinics, outreach/vaccination teams, transportation, infrastructures, money…). Maximizing the effectiveness of available resources is hence key, which is exactly what logistics, technology, and operations management is about.

This course provides an introduction to the important field of Health & Humanitarian Logistics and corresponding UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Though it covers some theory, the main focus will be on learning by doing. Through case studies, a simulation game, guest lectures from people who work in the humanitarian sector, individual and group exercises, you will work on real and complex challenges related to disaster relief, medicine supply chains, and health service delivery in low and middle income countries. Examples include: Where should one locate warehouses to pre-position relief goods? What/how much to stock there? What logistics network should one set up to handle incoming relief goods after a disaster? How to optimize the dispatching of these goods? What technology is useful to support relief activities? Should governments adopt a push or a pull system for medicine supplies to health facilities? Are vendor-managed inventories a solution for weak inventory management skills in pharmacies and clinics? Should drones be used to perform medicine deliveries? In what contexts should one use mobile (i.e., travelling) healthcare providers instead of traditional health facilities? How to screen for epidemic outbreaks?

Given the increasing need for smart use of data in this sector, much emphasis will be put on analyzing datasets and using analytics techniques to support decisions/ generate insights. While doing so, you will be asked to use the knowledge, methods, and models you have acquainted yourself with during your studies. If you have a background in logistics and supply chain management, you are encouraged to use data analysis and optimization techniques and mathematical models (e.g., for network design, planning, routing, and inventory control). If you are not familiar with these methods and models, you are encouraged to address the challenge using your intuition and methods and models you are familiar with. All students will be challenged to critically assess applicability of such methods and models (which have typically been developed to address business challenges) to the challenge considered. What are the hidden assumptions? What pieces can be transferred? What pieces need to be adjusted?
In parallel, the course will cover some basic concepts, background knowledge, and theory about Health & Humanitarian Logistics, including:

column2: • The goals the health & humanitarian system aims to achieve,
• The stakeholders in the health and humanitarian system,
• How the system works (or is supposed to work),
• The context in which health and humanitarian actors operate,
• Objectives and their quantification (e.g., through disease state modelling and epidemic modelling)
• The role of logistics in the system, and key logistics challenges,
• New technology (e.g., blockchain, drones) and new business models for addressing these challenges,
• Technology and management approaches for logistics decision making

column1: The main objective of this course is to introduce you to big open problems in the health and humanitarian sector, to critically assess transferability of business school knowledge, models, and methods and to creatively adjust or add to them.

Participation and in-person attendance of the sessions is highly recommended as much of the learning takes place there.  If you really cannot make it to a session, you should let the course instructor know well in advance via e-mail (harwin.devries@rsm.nl) and briefly explain why.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Explain the general goals the health & humanitarian system aims to achieve, the role of different stakeholders in this system, and the big challenges it is facing
• Analyze the role of logistics and applicability of related models (e.g., facility location, inventory control, planning, and routing) in addressing these challenges
• Adjust such models to account for the specifics of the challenge and context considered
• Generate solutions for/ insights on several of the logistics challenges
• Discuss the potential of new technologies, smart use of data, and business models to address challenges the health & humanitarian system is facing

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116607,2023,Health Care Ethics,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. KJ Grit', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? Following these meta-ethical questions, the course surveys major normative ethical theories (including utilitarianism, rights theory and virtue theory), describes methods of moral justification in healthcare ethics, addresses the problem of moral status and agency (what rights people are due, and when) and examines the moral characteristics of the basic relationships (e.g. professionals-patients and clients) inherent to healthcare.

Drawing from contemporary research, case studies and real-life examples, students will learn how the fundamental moral principles of autonomy, benevolence and justice can be expanded to apply to various conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare, from whether or not to withhold or withdraw life-sustaining treatments, to such diverse issues as the legislation of organ donation (opt-in or opt-out?), euthanasia and fulfilled lives, life style choices, access to collectively financed healthcare and solidarity, and expensive drugs and the worth of human life.

At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of moral philosophy
• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of health care ethics
• The student acquires basic moral reasoning skills
• The student is able to apply basic moral reasoning skills to real-life moral dilemmas in healthcare
• The student engages actively in moral discussions
• The student is able to hold a moral position convincingly, expressed in a well-written essay, based on well-researched arguments and sound logic

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112147,2023,Health Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['A Ahsen', 'dr. CL van Erpecum', 'prof.dr. FT Schut', 'prof.dr. JLW van Kippersluis', 'prof.dr. WBF Brouwer']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Advances in medical technology generate substantial improvements in population health, but also lead to rapidly rising health care costs. Population ageing both increases the need for health care and reduces the fraction of people working to pay for it and providing the necessary care. At the same time, health inequalities remain stubbornly high and further reduce productivity. How can we resolve these challenges?

This course will introduce students to economic analysis of health and health care. We will start by addressing the question of what makes health care a different economic good. The special features of health care mean that the standard economic tools are not sufficient to study its demand and supply. We will learn the main economic models that have been developed to analyse the demand and supply of health care and health insurance. This course will also provide an introduction to economic evaluation of health care. How much should we pay for an extra year in good health?
• Do doctors induce unnecessary demand for their services?
• Can poor people pay for their own health insurance?
• Should health insurance premia depend on how (un)healthy people are?
• How to determine the value/utility that people attach to health?
• What health care services should be included in the basic insurance package?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: • To become acquainted with the discipline of Health Economics.
• Understand the major theories in this field.
• Understand the main empirical work in this field.
• To be able to apply basics of methods for economic evaluation of health care.
• To be able to understand and critically assess published studies in health economics.
• To tackle a challenging and timely issue in health economics through an assignment

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>There will be a guest lecture this year from Dr. Matthijs Versteegh, who is an expert on Health Technology Assessment and working in the private sector. Additionally, there will be student presentations to representatives from the Ministry of Health.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113379,2023,Health Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[""prof.dr. OA O'Donnell""]",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. O.A. O’Donnell (EUR) and Prof. Dr. M. Lindeboom (VU)

This course examines how economics can be used to explain health behaviour, identify economic consequences of ill-health, and design health policy. It starts by evaluating the success of economic theory and empirical methods in explaining differences in health by education, wealth and income. It then considers effects of health on economic behaviour and outcomes. While the health economics research covered in the first two topics seeks to explain phenomena, the third and fourth topics turn to research with a prescriptive purpose: the design of policies to control communicable diseases and prevent non-communicable ones.

The fifth topic examines empirical strategies to identify causal effects of adverse circumstances early in life on human capital, labour market, and health outcomes in later life. Two conceptual frameworks are used to interpret the long shadow of early life conditions: the biological programming hypothesis and the pathways framework. Subsequently, a framework for parental investment in the cognitive and non-cognitive skills of children is considered. The final topic deals with the health effects of work in the later stages of working life and the measurement of health in social surveys.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Comprehend models and empirical methods used in health economics research,
2. Apply economic analysis to understand health behaviour and effects of health on economic behaviour and outcomes,
3. Appraise the validity of evidence on causal relationships between health and socioeconomic factors,
4. Use economics to evaluate the efficiency and equity of health policies,
5. Make a cogent critique of health economics research,
6. Present a concise, clear written argument related to a health phenomenon or policy founded on economic analysis with reference to relevant evidence from health economics research.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111077,2023,Health Psychology and Behavior Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['A Mamede Soares Braga, MSc', 'B Kemmere', 'dr. HA Harris', 'dr. I Merkelbach', 'dr. PL Kocken', 'MHL Hollaar, MSc', 'prof.dr. S Denktas']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course students will learn how they can use psychological theories to design and evaluate effective interventions. Together with our experts, they will take on the challenge to analyse, investigate and solve complex behavioral problems. They will start with exploring how psychological processes are linked to behaviors, and how they can use these insights to design interventions that change targeted behaviors and promote healthier choices.

The course will explore how psychological, behavioral and sociocultural factors influence health. The course will investigate how some of the most relevant societal challenges and health problems (e.g. behaviors related to infectious diseases, obesity, cancer) can be tackled through behavior change interventions. The course will give students the opportunity to apply the Behavior Change Wheel (BCW) for developing effective behavioral change interventions. This implies that, besides learning about behavior change theories, students will get hands-on experience with the steps involved in developing behavior change interventions to tackle current health problems.

column2: • Students will learn about theories on health psychology and behavior change and their applications in daily practice in weekly lectures. A series of show-cases from practice will be presented on a variety of topics, such as promoting healthy eating in school canteens, physical activity at work, prevention of sexual harassment and management of addictive behaviors.

• During the workshops, students will practice techniques of designing interventions. The steps of the BCW will be central. Experts will present examples of interventions and the ins and outs of design and implementation. The examples will focus on healthy eating in the first half of the workshops and on physical activity in the second half.
• The workshops will be rich on assignments taken from practice on which student work together using interactive learning activities.

column1: Upon completion of the course students should have provided evidence of being able to demonstrate a sophisticated, in-depth, and critical understanding of theory, assessment and intervention regarding psychological approaches to health. They are also able to critically and creatively evaluate current issues, research and advanced scholarship in the area of psychological approaches to health.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course you will be able to...

column2: • Outline the magnitude of a public health problem with available evidence from recognized resources.
• Identify from the available evidence what health risk factors, behavioral determinants, and sociocultural factors influence public health problems.
• Distinguish theories and models of health behavior
• Estimate behavior change theories and techniques in public health by addressing their strengths and limitations.
• Argue the challenges of behavior change interventions and policies to intervene in the public health problems in today's society.
• Apply the Behavior Change Wheel framework for developing effective behavior change interventions (BCIs) to tackle current health problems.
• Systematically design a behavior change intervention based on theory and empirical evidence, and professionally and convincingly present the intervention proposal, both oral and in writing.
• Critically judge scientific publications in the field of behavior change and its effect studies, accounting for methodological rigor, theoretical soundness, and relevance.
• Distinguish stakeholders in the field of public health and analyze their aims and counterarguments concerning behavior change interventions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113234,2023,Health Psychology: Understanding Health Behaviour,Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Why do people smoke, refuse vaccination, have unsafe sex, eat unhealthily and are physically inactive despite the health risks? How can we help individuals, communities and societies to live healthier and maintain these behaviours to prevent illness? In this course, we will explain how health psychology can be used to address behaviours that can affect our health. We will do this by (1) explaining how biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors contribute to physical, mental, and social wellbeing, and by (2) exploring health promotion intervention design in a hands-on manner, using the intervention mapping approach. This course is about theory, evidence, practical applications and a glimpse into the real-world.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:

column2: • Understand the reasons underlying the emergence of health psychology;
• Have a basic understanding of the public health consequences of hypertension, diabetes, and sexually transmitted diseases;
• Understand the determinants of health behaviour and identify effective methods of promoting behaviour change and healthier lifestyles;
• Understand the main health risks and positive health behaviours that are relevant to the population at large;
• Understand the role of health behaviours for determining health outcomes;
• Become familiar with behaviour change theories in public health;
• Identify trends in research about the evidence based clinical behaviour of health care professionals;
• Discuss the role of theories and techniques of behaviour change;
• Learn from the experiences of a GP working in the South of Rotterdam;
• Understand sociocultural differences of health and illness;
• Become familiar with a theoretical framework to understand cultural differences and similarities;
• Apply behaviour change theories to design a pilot intervention focused on hypertension/diabetes/sexual and reproductive health;
• Appreciate the challenges and opportunities associated with running an intervention in the field.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116867,2023,Health Service Operations Management,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. S Sülz', 'dr.ir. SG Elkhuizen', 'prof.dr.ir. CTB Ahaus', 'prof.dr.ir. JMH Vissers']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Health Service Operations Management (HSOM) can be defined as the analysis, design, planning and control of all steps necessary to deliver services to clients in healthcare. We use methods and techniques that originate from manufacturing but have been adapted to service industries and health services.

The aim of the course is to make the students familiar with the basic concepts, methods and techniques of health service operations management and to enable them to apply these concepts to services in healthcare. We will focus on the development of health service operations management as a field of research, its relevance to develop and improve health services and on the basic concepts of health service operations management. We will use Operations Management theory and concepts for the operations management of individual units within health service provider organizations (e.g. a ward) and for the operations management of care pathways (e.g. mamma cancer diagnosis and treatment) and care chains (e.g. stroke services).

Furthermore we will discuss the concepts underlying Focused Factory, Lean Management, Six Sigma, Business Process Redesign and Theory of Constraints as these are popular approaches in operations management used in continuous improvement of processes in health services. All topics will be introduced in lectures and put into practice in workgroups. Quantitative analyses (with Excel) will be part of both the working group assignments and the individual assignment. To prepare, test and update your Excel knowledge, a formative test in excel is available on the website (Excel skills).
Language: The workgroups for ZoMa are in Dutch, lectures and working groups for HCM are in English. Exams are in English, but ZoMa students are allowed to answer questions in Dutch.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The student can apply definitions, concepts and methods of Health Service Operations Management.
• The student can perform quantitative analyses with Excel.
• The student can analyse the performance of health service delivery systems.
• The student can apply concepts of HSOM to evaluate and improve services for healthcare delivery.
• The student can provide support for solutions suggested, based on the theory of health service operations management.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116866,2023,Health Service Operations Management,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. S Sülz', 'dr.ir. SG Elkhuizen', 'prof.dr.ir. CTB Ahaus', 'prof.dr.ir. JMH Vissers']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We will focus on the development of health service operations management as a field of research, its relevance to develop and improve health services and on the basic concepts of health service operations management. We will use Operations Management theory and concepts for the operations management of individual units within health service provider organizations (e.g. a ward) and for the operations management of care pathways (e.g. mamma cancer diagnosis and treatment) and care chains (e.g. stroke services).

Furthermore we will discuss the concepts underlying Focused Factory, Lean Management, Six Sigma, Business Process Redesign and Theory of Constraints as these are popular approaches in operations management used in continuous improvement of processes in health services. All topics will be introduced in lectures and put into practice in workgroups. Quantitative analyses (with Excel) will be part of both the working group assignments and the individual assignment. To prepare, test and update your Excel knowledge, a formative test in excel is available on the website (Excel skills).

A van Dongen - Leunis', 'dr. E Birnie', 'dr. HM Blommestein', 'dr. NSH Xander, MSc', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'H Mokri', 'prof.dr. MPMH Rutten - van Molken', 'S Azzouz, MSc', 'T Belleman', 'YH Chen, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Although patients demand access to all health care programmes available, the scarcity of resources necessitates that choices have to be made. Given that health is such an important matter and that choices usually have far reaching consequences for individuals, the choices require careful consideration, preferably based on transparent and unbiased data. Health Technology Assessment is a multidisciplinary research area closely related to health economics. HTA research attempts to examine the short- and long-term consequences (e.g. health effects and costs) of new and existing health care programs. This is done in a systematic and consistent way in order to provide evidence for the relative cost- effectiveness of health care programs. Policy makers in health care are increasingly using the results of these studies in making choices on priorities in health care.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course you will learn how to perform and critically review a HTA.
By the end of the course students can:

column2: • describe the structure and the objectives of HTA/economic evaluation studies.
• perform the 6 steps of an economic evaluation study.
• describe and discuss the inclusion, measurement and valuation of future costs, productivity costs, informal care and outcomes beyond the QALY in economic evaluations
• explain advantages and disadvantages of various quality of life instruments and can discuss when and how individual instruments should be used.
• explain the relationship between several economic theories and the differences in operationalization of key concepts in economic evaluation studies.
• perform and interpret cost- and cost-effectiveness calculations including analysis of uncertainty with a decision tree and a Markov disease model and reflect upon the design and quality of studies.
• critically discuss the inclusion of economic evaluations among other policy ingredients in policy reimbursement decisions of new health care interventions.
• explain the difficulties of transferring outcomes of economic evaluations across jurisdictions.

column1: This course examines the links between health, health expenditure and economic development at the macro and at micro level.
-Health and economic development at the macro level
-Health, behavior and productivity at the micro level
-Public provision of health, health expenditure and its pitfalls
-Recent advances in empirical research of health and development
-Identification strategies in the field of health and development

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course aims to critically examine the inter-linkage between health and economic development at the macro and micro level both theoretically and empirically.
-Introduce concepts of health and its measurement in the field of development economics
-Illustrate the theoretical links between health and economic development
-Discuss theories of health behaviors and investments
-Critically analyze economic and political mechanisms in the field of health service provision
-Introduce theoretical frameworks and causal, empirical tools to study the linkage between health and economic development</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115135,2023,Healthcare Ethics,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. J Weenink', 'dr. KJ Grit', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'FA Tallgren', 'K Trujillo Jara', 'MJ Kersing, MSc', 'prof.dr. RA Bal', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? Following these meta-ethical questions, the course surveys major normative ethical theories (including utilitarianism, rights theory and virtue theory), describes methods of moral justification in healthcare ethics, addresses the problem of moral status and agency (what rights people are due, and when) and examines the moral characteristics of the basic relationships (e.g. professionals-patients and clients) inherent to healthcare.

Drawing from contemporary research, case studies and real-life examples, students will learn how the fundamental moral principles of autonomy, benevolence and justice can be expanded to apply to various conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare, from whether or not to withhold or withdraw life-sustaining treatments, to such diverse issues as the legislation of organ donation (opt-in or opt-out?), euthanasia and fulfilled lives, life style choices, access to collectively financed healthcare and solidarity, and expensive drugs and the worth of human life.

At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of moral philosophy
• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of health care ethics
• The student acquires basic moral reasoning skills
• The student is able to apply basic moral reasoning skills to real-life moral dilemmas in healthcare
• The student engages actively in moral discussions
• The student is able to hold a moral position convincingly, expressed in a well-written essay, based on well-researched arguments and sound logic

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116966,2023,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Organisations are part of chains and networks in which actors collaborate and compete to create value. Actors in the value chain procure goods and/or services from suppliers and provide goods and/or services to customers. Organisations do not operate in isolation but are dependent on suppliers and customers. These interactions lead to buyer-supplier relationships. In this course we will focus on the procurement function of healthcare organisations. The procurement function’s main task is to secure inputs (goods, services, knowledge and human capital) from suppliers against the most favourable conditions.

In healthcare value chains two types of purchasing can be distinguished: purchasing of healthcare and purchasing for healthcare. In purchasing of healthcare, which is done by for instance healthcare insurance companies, ‘healthcare’ is the service that is purchased. In purchasing for healthcare a diverse set of goods and services is purchased (e.g. medical equipment, hospital beds, but also catering and temporary labour).

A significant amount of money is spent in the healthcare industry on a yearly basis, which makes that there is a large potential for the purchasing profession to decrease spend, improve quality and increase innovation as well as efficiency. In this course we connect management theory about purchasing with specific characteristics of the healthcare industry.

The objective of this course is to provide students with the key concepts regarding purchasing and supply management and apply such concepts to the healthcare sector. Students will get to understand the role that purchasing plays within and between healthcare organisations and the different ways in which purchasing can contribute to value creation in a healthcare system. Students are able to reflect on the importance of purchasing in their own organisations so that they can collaborate, as a non-purchasing professional, with the purchasing department to contribute to the overall performance of their organisation.
Attendance of the lectures is expected and strongly recommended. The workshops have mandatory attendance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management to create value in healthcare systems and justify why high purchasing maturity is important
• Understand the different ways in which value can be operationalized and apply this knowledge to a variety of stakeholders in the healthcare system
• Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships and evaluate which incentives are appropriate to create value in such relationships

• Understand the importance of different types of relationships within and between organisations and compare the advantages and disadvantages of different ways to structure and govern such relationships
• Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and evaluate how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care
• Can articulate a question for a guest lecturer based on their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care

• Can apply their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care to cases of real healthcare organizations, diseases/conditions, and/or patient groups, and create an argumentation how purchasing and supply management can deliver value in that case

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115187,2023,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['PJG Dohmen, MSc', 'prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Health care providers are dependent on suppliers for the production and delivery of the services they provide to their customers. In the same vein, health care financers (such as health insurers) are dependent on the health care providers to supply health care services to their clients. In both cases, the purchasing function has the responsibility to secure external inputs (goods, services, knowledge, people) from the suppliers against the best possible conditions.

In the health care supply chain, we distinguish between purchasing of health care and purchasing for health care. When we speak of purchasing of health care, the health care is the product that is purchased (e.g., care or cure purchased by health insurers). When we speak of purchasing for health care, we are looking at a broad spectrum of goods and services needed by health care providers, such as medical devices, temporary labor, catering, and much more. Health care represents a considerable portion of public (and private) spending, and therefore, various entities (such as the WHO, as well as the Dutch NZa and RVS) are pointing towards professional purchasing management as a possible contributor to cost containment, quality improvement, innovation, and productivity enhancement in the health care sector.
In this course, we connect management theory in the area of purchasing and supply management to the specific characteristics of the health care sector.

Understand the different ways in which value can be operationalized and apply this knowledge to a variety of stakeholders in the healthcare system;

Understand the importance of different types of relationships within and between organisations and compare the advantages and disadvantages of different ways to structure and govern such relationships;
Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and evaluate how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care;
Can articulate a question for a guest lecturer based on their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care;

Can apply their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care to cases of real healthcare organizations, diseases/conditions, and/or patient groups, and create an argumentation how purchasing and supply management can create value in that case.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114253,2023,Heffingen lokale overheden,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. A Schoneveld', 'mr. FJHL Makkinga', 'prof.mr.dr. AW Schep']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak Heffingen lokale overheden behandelt de gemeentelijke belastingen en retributies en plaatst dit specialistische vakgebied in perspectief ten opzichte van het gehele fiscale stelsel.

Daarbij is, naast kennis van de lokale belastingen, die veelal een geheel eigen karakter hebben, ook inzicht in de structuur van dit nog steeds groeiende belastinggebied van belang. De verbondenheid van de belastingverordeningen dient kritisch te kunnen worden beoordeeld. Gegeven de veelvuldige wijzigingen (ook in dit deel van het belastingrecht) dient inzicht te worden verkregen in de materiële gevolgen van implementatie van nieuwe regelgeving, waaronder het steeds bredere gebruik van de WOZ-waarde, bijvoorbeeld in de inkomstenbelasting en in de vennootschapsbelasting (de beperking van de afschrijving op gebouwen ingevolge de Wet Werken aan Winst).

Heffingen lokale overheden richt zich op een uitwerking van diverse belastingen en rechten die gemeenten, provincies en waterschappen heffen, alsmede op de Wet waardering onroerende zaken, haar uitvoeringsregels en de taxatiemethoden.
Daarnaast komt de toepassing van rechtsbeginselen in ruime mate aan bod, zoals de werking van het gelijkheidsbeginsel en het evenredigheidsbeginsel.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de grondslagen en beginselen van het lokale belastingrecht alsmede de verhouding van dit belastingrecht tot andere rechtsgebieden
• heeft de student grondige kennis en inzicht in de essentialia van de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede in de werking van de Wet WOZ
• kan de student het gelijkheids- en het evenredigheidsbeginsel toepassen op de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede andere rechts- en fiscale beginselen toepassen
• heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de totstandkoming en inhoud van verordeningen en lokale belastingen, alsmede in de heffing en invordering van deze heffingen
• heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de maatschappelijke rol van het lokale belastingrecht en de acceptatie van burgers van deze heffingen
• kan de student juridische teksten, waaronder wetgeving (mede hieronder begrepen verdragen), jurisprudentie en wetenschappelijke literatuur begrijpen, analyseren en kritisch beoordelen
• kan de student binnen een bepaalde tijdsspanne antwoord geven op fiscaalrechtelijke casus uit de lokale belastingpraktijk in de vorm van een schriftelijk stuk

• heeft de student vaardigheid opgedaan om te komen tot een onderbouwde juridische argumentatie met betrekking tot de werking van rechtsbeginselen, essentialia van belastingen en de werking van de Wet WOZ, en de bewijsvoering

• heeft de student inzicht gekregen in de werking van het fiscale bestuurs(proces)recht door analyse van WOZ- en andere fiscale bezwaar- en beroepsprocedures en door oefening van argumentatie in die procedures

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114723,2023,Heritage and Fashion,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. B Wubs'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The fashion industry is a paradigmatic sector of post-industrial economies, whose products increasingly rely on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local heritage and specificities. The fashion industry revolves around a myriad of key locations around the world, yet this has been the case for an extended period of time. A polycentric geography of fashion emerged, integrating traditional supply chains with digital technologies. Some luxury brands, such as Louis Vuitton, are even engaging with blockchain to prove the authenticity of their products. Topics covered in the course, among others: place, space and heritage in the fashion industry, storytelling, craftsmanship, temporary fashion clusters, and policies for fashion. In particular, storytelling appears to be an important tool for the fashion industry due to the necessity to differentiate the various products or brands and to add emotional value to them. Heritage and tradition are at the core of storytelling. Even new fashion products and brands are imbued with a historical flavor and sense of legendary quality, with the help of storytelling and revived craftsmanship. Given the rise of sustainability concerns, storytelling and craftsmanship, and in general heritage, are gaining momentum for the fashion industry and other creative industries too.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
•          Students have a thorough knowledge and understanding of how the fashion industry and heritage are intertwined.
•          Students can analyze the place, space, and heritage of the fashion industry from business history and cultural economics perspectives.
•          Students are able to present and discuss the results of their analysis with peers and with fashion stakeholders.
•          Students learn how to write a case study and teaching notes and can eventually pitch those at the end of the course.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115893,2023,Het (moderne en postmoderne) subject,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. RBJM Welten'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het moderne subject als autonoom en rationeel individu werd geboren in de gedachten van Descartes en Kant, zo wordt beweerd. Maar tijdens de 20e eeuw tot heden trekken veel filosofen de vrijheid, rationaliteit en coherentie van het subject in twijfel. Is het subject wel zo autonoom en vrij als het meent te zijn? Is het wel wat het denkt dat het is? In welke mate zijn we bepaald door de maatschappelijke, culturele, economische en politieke aard?

In deze cursus zullen we nagaan hoe het huidige beeld van de mens als een autonoom, rationeel individu zich heeft ontwikkeld en op welke grenzen het stuit. We bespreken klassieke teksten uit de subjectfilosofie en analyseren de kritiek aan deze posities van denkers uit de 20e en 21e eeuw waaronder Freud, Kierkegaard, Camus, Sartre, De Beauvoir, Barthes, Lacan en Žižek. Daarbij zal duidelijk worden dat niet enkel het concept van het subject, maar ook het filosofische denken zelf altijd ingebed ligt in omstandigheden van maatschappelijke, culturele en politieke aard en dat die elkaar over en weer beïnvloeden.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Zowel de hoorcolleges als de werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten Filosofie.

Aan het einde van de cursus heeft de student/e inzicht in de verschillende concepten van het subject via de wordingsgeschiedenis daarvan en de kritische uiteenzettingen daarmee in de moderne tijd. Ze/hij is in staat om de argumenten in de behandelde teksten te identificeren en samen te vatten. Zij/hij geeft een onderbouwde redenering over de deugdelijkheid van de genoemde kritiekpunten (die gericht zijn tegen het concept van een autonoom een rationeel subject).

column1: This course offers an overview of how to find, analyse and use primary, secondary and tertiary sources for historical research. Students will learn how they can find and evaluate these sources using traditional resources, such as bibliographies, book reviews and reference works, but they also  have  to  familiarise  themselves  with new research methods  such as  online  databases  and Internet sources. Students  not only  learn how to find these sources, they  also acquire  the  skills  to  organise  and evaluate  all this  information. They can find  this  information on the  internet,  but they  also  have  to  visit libraries  and archives  to  collect the most relevant data for their research. Students will be introduced to historiographical debates and will learn how to identify debates relevant to their research. They will also learn to write a structural analysis of these historiographical debates.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will learn how scholarly information is communicated and how they have to credit other academics’ work in their research. They can find and evaluate primary, secondary and tertiary sources, and identify and use different types of sources in historical research. Students  will be able to find relevant source material in libraries, archives and on the internet, using digital tools for historical research. Students will learn how to write a structural analysis and to analyse historiographical debates.
