column1: Leaders are key players in organizational functioning because they critically affect the people they work with—both inside and outside of their organization. Leaders are in a unique position to mobilise employees to excel and contribute to the organisation’s mission and vision. At the same time, however, they may also be a primary source of conflict and demotivation. Understanding what makes for high performance leadership as well as where leadership can go wrong, therefore, is of critical importance to any aspiring leader; and for HR professionals who may come to take the lead of the HR organization, as well as facilitate the process of leadership in their organization.

In this course, we address one key question: “what makes an effective leader?” from a range of different theoretical perspectives (e.g., social identity, visionary leadership) and cast in the context of contemporary workplace trends (e.g., demographic change, digitization). Through a sequence of readings, lectures, cases, and experiential exercises, students learn to understand and apply state-of-the-art leadership theories, analyse and evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failures, as well as apply these learnings to make recommendations for real-world leadership challenges.
No more than 5 missed sessions. If students missed more than 5 sessions, they will not qualify for the assessment of the course, and therefore will not be able to pass the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Apply relevant theories and concepts determining leadership effectiveness at the individual, relational, team, and organizational levels.
• Evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failures, using relevant leadership concepts and theories, applied to everyday observations.
• Formulate evidence-based recommendations for contemporary leadership challenges.
• Evaluate common leadership myths/maxims using an evidence-based mindset.

• Apply relevant leadership theories and concepts to your own personal leadership challenges and situations (e.g., vision communication, difficult conversations) through experimentation and reflection.

column1: The discipline of sociology was established during (and to make sense of) the process of modernisation. A core characteristic of modernisation is rapid social change, and sociology theorises and studies such changes by comparing traditional societies to modern societies. The perspectives that were developed and the topics addressed by the founders of the discipline are still relevant today, because they regard issues as socioeconomic inequality, social order and deviance, the role of religion and ideology, gender relations, what it means to live in an urbanised world, the relation of individuals with society. In this course we learn about these classic perspectives by looking at contemporary societies. We will learn to apply the ‘sociological imagination’ to everyday life as well as study the classic sociological questions using present-day cases. Assessment consists of a final exam and an essay.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After this course, students will be able to describe and apply the three most important sociological perspectives (functionalism, conflict sociology, symbolic interactionism) to issues such as modernization, inequality, cohesion and individualization.

In addition, students are able to reproduce the meaning of and theory formation around the following key concepts: Scientific paradigms; Identity performance; Political distrust; Gender segregation in the labour market; Deviance and social problems; Religion and Atheism; Sociology of Globalization.</body>

column1: ""Historical Culture in a Globalizing World"" studies the multifaceted ways in which societies engage with their pasts. It encompasses the varied narratives and performative practices employed for socio-political purposes, along with the infrastructures preserved to commemorate, communicate, and conserve history. We will study the inherently political nature of historical culture, analyzing how conflicting conceptions of history are used to shape a societal understanding of the relationship between past, present, and future. Furthermore, this course underscores the roles these historical narratives play in validating and reinforcing specific ideologies and worldviews, as well as the political and ideological tensions that they generate or deliberately fuel. Students will critically engage with the complexities of historical truth, historical justice, memory distortion, and the construction of historical myths.

Key topics covered in the course include the politics of memory and forgetting, the role of education in shaping historical consciousness, the relationship between history and nationalism, the role of heritage in war and conflict, and the impact of historical culture on reconciliation processes and post-conflict societies.

column1: This course focuses on the various ways history is represented through the written word, images, films, interactive media, games and re-enactments, and how these representations affect how history is understood, experienced and made meaningful. Starting with theories of representation as it applies to historical topics, the course will explore how historical representation is a mediation of the past, and a remediation of prior representations of history. We will discuss some interesting case-studies in which we apply the concepts from the literature. Students will create their own historical representations, discuss the concepts in the readings, apply their leaning in written work and a presentation.

They can contextualize and critically assess these images of the past in view of its functions for specific communities. They are capable to produce written papers and oral presentations on relevant topics of this course, based on the discussed concepts.

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4 , preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, where after students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
-  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

The term Creative Industries is a relatively recent concept coined in the late 1990s by new labour in Britain. Ever since this contested concept has evolved into an important policy instrument of national and local governments, the European Union, and United Nations, as well as a lively academic discourse. The workshop aims to historicize the concept and explore the historical roots of the creative industries and aims to analyse different sectors of the industry, including fashion, art markets, film, radio, television, music, design, theatre, tourism and video games. Furthermore, this course looks at innovations within large and small firms and networks across a range of industries. It explores the role of institutions and organizations, in particular governments or similar gatekeeping structures, and the diversity of innovation processes and across different sectors of the economy in the long twentieth century. Finally, it focuses on the effects of innovation and creativity on economic growth, international competitiveness, and employment. Different theoretical approaches emphasising cultural, national, regional, local, and firm-based factors, will be explored and applied to case studies selected by the students. During the first eight weeks students will learn how to design their own research which fits into the general theme of the workshop and will finally submit a research proposal which will form the basis for their master thesis. During the third and fourth term students will discuss their progress and share their inspiration (What inspires you?) with their peers.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October

column1: <body>This course will teach students how to work with primary sources and which methodologies to apply in order to uncover the recent history of diversity. Oral history and interviewing will be core skills in this course. Students will learn how to conduct interviews in a professional and critical way without neglecting the emotional and ethical dimensions of this method. They will discover the theoretical and practical dimensions of an oral history project during lectures and field work; will learn how to combine different methodologies, including digital tools in research and how to communicate the findings to wider public. The course will also teach students how to analyse and map photographs in an urban context and will offer the possibility to use GIS software to place these photos in urban space. Pictures can show how marginalised groups made use of public space and how their representations can be distorted by the gaze of dominant groups in society.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The learning goal of this course is twofold:

(1) History of psychology: Many of our psychological questions today existed for a long time and date back to ancient Greece. The course provides a short overview of the long history of psychology and how psychological questions have been addressed through the centuries in a variety of ways. Moreover, the course looks at the emergence of psychology as an independent scientific disciple 150 years ago and sketches its devolvement since then.

(2) <u>Fundamental issues of psychology as a science.</u> Psychologists need to able to critically evaluate and discuss the basic research principles and fundamental methods of their disciple. We study some basic ideas of the philosophy of science and apply it to modern psychological research and the debate on open science. The central questions are: Is Psychology science or is it just pseudoscience? What are the criteria for science? What are good and bad research practices? We want to understand moreover the current contribution of psychology to modern research on behavior. Do we still need psychology in times, in which neuroscience is rapidly progressing and providing explanations of behavior on a neuronal level? </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • You will develop a basic understanding of the historical roots of psychological as scientific disciple.
• You will have basic knowledge of what the field of philosophy of mind and philosophy of science entails.
• You will have an understanding and critical view on the criteria of science and its demarcation from pseudoscience.
• You will have a basic understanding of epistemological theories and their implications for the methods of psychology.
• You will develop a critical view on psychology as a scientific disciple and the ongoing debate on the replication crisis.
• You will be able to identify questionable research practices in empirical science.
• You will become familiar with the methods of open science and the other methods aiming to address the discussed problems in behavioral science.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course starts with an overview of the major founders of the social sciences (Adam Smith, Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim and Max Weber). These early social scientists assume that the rise of modernity around 1800 was a milestone in world history. They believe that early modern society was profoundly transformed by industrialisation, secularisation, democratisation and urbanisation. This particular view on historical developments is heavily criticised by historians, because of its Eurocentric, deterministic and teleological approach. However, these theories still offer an interesting starting-point for historical research, because modernisation theories laid the foundation of our modern, western self-awareness and is still frequently used to explain global historical developments. Some of the twentieth-century elaborations of these early social theories are discussed in this course. A critical reflection on current developments is also part of this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students learn to identify and recognise similarities and differences between social sciences and history. They can define some key concepts of the social sciences and place them in their historical context. They can explain and critically analyse modernisation theories. They can connect social theory with empirical research based on historical sources.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114674,2023,History of Early Modern Societies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['BC Fici, MA', 'dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'ED van der Wiel', 'N Sikkema', 'R van Velzen, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the early modern period, Western societies set their first steps towards modernity. In this process, they ultimately set off on a path diverging from the rest of the world. Most historians will agree on this part of the story, but it is still under debate how, why and when this divergence started. Did it    start with the American war of independence, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution or had the wheels of change already been set in motion long before? Did Europe feel born again as it set out to discover the unknown after the Plague? Were the religious 'dark-ages' eventually  enlightened by the Renaissance and reason? And to what extent did international trade provide the inspiration for and precede industrialisation? During this course, it will be critically assessed whether these changes were indigenous to Europe or should be viewed just as much as a result of Europe’s interaction with the rest of the world. In the lectures and tutorials, we will ask ourselves the question if historians have too easily projected their view of the world today on the past, instead of seeing early modern societies as different and unique in their own right.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Students are introduced to the history of early modern societies between 1300 and 1750. They will acquire new insights into the structural changes that took place in Europe and in the wider world during this period. Students are able to analyse historical argumentative texts and use this skill of the so-called structure analysis in producing papers and an oral presentation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course offers a short introduction to the history of some important ideas in microeconomics, macroeconomics and empirical methods. A frequent theme will be that the writings of earlier generations of economists were frequently much less naïve than they are often made out to be and, in some cases, economists held views diametrically opposed to those with which they are often associated. For example, Adam Smith did not advocate the unchecked pursuit of self-interest, Maynard Keynes did not attribute unemployment to sticky wages, and Keynesian economists of the 1950s and 1960s well understood the potential for high demand to create accelerating inflation.

Sessions will involve a mixture of lecturing and discussion, and students will be expected to do a limited amount of reading before classes and to participate in discussions. One reason for this is so that students can turn the discussion to topics that interest them. More extensive reading will then be required for assignments, related to their own interest, which in many cases means students’ students’ research interests; the topics for these are worked out in consultation with the teacher.

The coverage can vary according to student demand, but topics that could be covered as part of the core include: the history of general equilibrium theory, game theory and welfare economics; the Keynesian revolution and monetarism; the history of the Phillips curve and DSGE modeling; the history of econometrics and empirical methods.

To write a well structured argument.
To appreciate the historical setting of economic arguments.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114676,2023,History of Modern Societies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JJ Euwe', 'dr. N da Silva Perez', 'ED van der Wiel', 'MRM Straver, MSC MA', 'R van Velzen, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>From the middle of the eighteenth century, the industrial revolution, the spread of Enlightenment ideas and the rise of Romanticism, and the political revolutions in America and France created a structural transformation of Western Europe. A core notion that emerged, and that will serve as our central theme, is the contested idea of progress: the belief that humans are able to understand the world and improve it on the basis of that understanding. Each week we will focus on a specific theme that illustrates this basic idea and its critics. The first week is devoted to the rise of the new interventionist state from Napoleonic France on, the beginning of what would later be called the welfare state. During the second week we will study class conflicts in the nineteenth century, in connection with the increasing internationalization of the economy. Week three is devoted to the crisis of democracies during the interwar period, with a focus on the rise of fascism. In week four we will study the making of the modern material environment, especially the world-wide impact of modernist architecture, design, and city planning.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course provides an introduction to the history of western societies since 1750. Structural changes in politics, culture and the economy are discussed. In addition, students are trained to close-read and interpret primary sources from this period and to report their findings in oral and written presentations.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114599,2023,History of Western Arts and Culture,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AC Crotta', 'E Aktug, MSc', 'GA Giolo Rego, MSc', 'GF Pires', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'MF Rodriguez Rodriguez']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course History of Western Arts and Culture provides a historical and chronological overview of Western art and culture from the late Middle Ages until the 21st century. Students get acquainted with the major developments in the visual arts, architecture, music, and literature from this period, against a historical background. It is demonstrated how the highlights from these disciplines originate from, reflect, and shape the socio-cultural context of their time, and how these historical developments continue to have their effects on contemporary culture.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

History of Western Arts and Culture is intended for first-year students of the International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies/Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen. The aim is to provide them with a historical and versatile foundation for their further studies. Students will acquire a historical overview of the main developments and trends in Western art and culture, and gain insight into how the various disciplines (visual arts, literature, architecture and music) are interrelated.  Furthermore, students will gain insight into the way in which art comes from, reflects on, and at the same time shapes the socio-cultural context of its time. Finally, students will acquire knowledge on how the position of the artist in relation to fellow artists, clients and the public has developed historically.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114620,2023,History of the Art Market,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['CA Malig Jedlicki, MSc', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'prof.dr. FRR Vermeylen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will provide an introduction to the history of the Dutch and European art markets, and the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution and consumption of art will be discussed. Attention will be given - among other topics - to the innovations that were introduced to expand the market for works of art since early modern times. For instance the development and growing importance of art auctions from the seventeenth century until the present will be examined in detail, as well as other more recent developments such as the impact of new media on the art market.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 55.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The course seeks to familiarize the students with the history and functioning of early modern and modern art markets. They will be exposed to the recent findings concerning the socio-economic, but also the cultural and sociological framework in which works of art were and are produced, traded and consumed. An interdisciplinary approach will be pursued in order to gain insight into these phenomena.</body>

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master's thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, whereafter students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:

column2: • discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
• discussion of and information on possible research methods
• discussion of case studies and other work in progress
• discussion of case studies and other work in progress
• presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June

column1: -  participation in discussions following presentations The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

History and memory are analytically distinct, but overlapping concepts. The significance of both concepts is closely related to the emergence of nation states and their colonial empires, and to the professionalization of the pursuit of history. In this course we discuss the relationship between history and memory, and how this relationship has changed over time due to fundamental changes in society, such as the French Revolution, the emergence of mass culture, secularization, two world wars, new media, globalization, and transformations in historical scholarship. We will also study specific applications of these concepts in examples of (popular) historical culture, such as the construction of the nation state, heritage and public history.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

column1: Following the political revolutions of the late eighteenth century, the organising role of the state in a society that was no longer based on a hierarchy of orders and estates was fiercely debated in Europe and the United States. This debate was further intensified by the major effects of industrialisation in the English Midlands and subsequently elsewhere in Europe. The ideologies that still frame and inform debates today – conservatism, socialism, liberalism, nationalism and so on – emerged at that time. While industrialisation, economic growth and imperialism led to technological advances and levels of prosperity the likes of which the world had not seen before, they also caused social and environmental disruption on a global scale. Wars caused destruction on an unprecedented scale, social bonds that had defined the fabric of society for centuries were broken and even the biosphere was affected. In the context of seeking solutions to such problems, reference was repeatedly made to the state and, increasingly, also to the need for cooperation between states. The development of this thinking since the eighteenth century is the subject of this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The purpose of this course is to study themes that are covered elsewhere in the bachelor’s degree programme in greater depth. Students will be introduced to historical thinkers and their theories regarding the state and the relationship between state and society. Students will develop the ability to place these thinkers and their works in their respective contexts. Students will read primary texts/sources. Students will learn how to independently initiate and structure a meaningful discussion.

column1: De Honours Class is er voor studenten die gemotiveerd zijn om naast de reguliere vakken een verdiepend studieprogramma te volgen.

Je kiest aan het begin van de Honours Class het zorg-gerelateerde onderwerp waar je tijdens de rest van de Honours Class aan werkt. Vervolgens specificeer je leerdoelen – wat wil je over dit onderwerp leren? – en maak je een plan hoe je die doelen gaat bereiken en hoe je door middel van de door jou zelf gespecificeerde producten gaat bewijzen dat je de doelen behaald hebt. Uit je leerdoelen en je plan blijkt dat je aandacht hebt voor kennis én voor vaardigheden. Je producten maak je voor jezelf maar ook voor anderen waar je in je studie mee te maken krijgt; van je producten is er minstens een die interessant is voor een onderzoeker, een voor een beleidsmaker en een voor een manager.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Leerdoelen opstellen die in lijn zijn met je kernwaarden;
• Een planning maken waarin je specificeert en beargumenteert welke stappen je onderneemt om je doelen te bereiken, in welke volgorde je dat doet, en welke hulpbronnen je daarbij nodig hebt;
• Reflecteren op je eigen vooruitgang, zowel wat betreft het maken van producten als het aanleren van vaardigheden;
• Medestudenten op correcte wijze feedback geven en constructief omgaan met feedback die je van medestudenten krijgt;
• Een aantrekkelijke presentatie geven aan medestudenten over een studie-gerelateerd onderwerp;
• Je zelfstandig verdiepen in de onderzoeks-, beleids- en managementaspecten van een zorggerelateerd onderwerp en hier verslag van doen;
• Een inhoudelijke bijeenkomst organiseren over een zorg-gerelateerd onderwerp.

column1: Engaging, challenging and creative; The IBCoM Honours Programme gives ambitious students access to opportunities and challenges beyond the normal scope of the undergraduate program. Students’ own contribution in the HP’s curriculum—through engagement in interactive sessions, presentation of their own work, portfolio assignments and the organization of the Honours Alliance networking event and Honours Symposium —further enables them to actively explore new areas of interest.
The course is organized in two modules, and an honours symposium at the end.

The IBCoM Honours Programme is an extracurricular programme by invitation only. Students with a first-year GPA of 7,5 or higher will get the opportunity to apply. A limited number of applicants can be accepted.

column1: In deze minor zul je op kennismaken met een aantal belangrijke inzichten uit de Psychologie.

De psychologie is een wetenschappelijke discipline die probeert het gedrag, de gedachten, gevoelens en drijfveren van mensen te begrijpen, te verklaren en te voorspellen. Na deze minor Hoogtepunten uit de psychologie zul je beter begrijpen waarom mensen doen wat ze doen. Meer begrip van menselijk gedrag kan buitengewoon relevant zijn voor alle disciplines waar mensen de hoofdrol spelen. Denk bijvoorbeeld aan de economie, de rechtspraak, de bedrijfskunde, de politicologie, maar ook in de bouwkunde of de ICT. We hopen dat de kennis die je in deze minor op doet van toegevoegde waarde is voor je huidige studie. Maar we hopen vooral dat je door meer kennis van de psychologie ook meer kennis van jezelf krijgt.

De psychologie is een enorm vakgebied. Natuurlijk kunnen we in het tijdsbestek van één minor niet alle belangrijke psychologische inzichten de revue laten passeren. Daarom hebben we een selectie gemaakt van een aantal van de meest tot de verbeelding sprekende theorieën en ontdekkingen. Deze komen onder andere voort uit de sociale psychologie, de persoonlijkheidsleer, de biologische psychologie en de klinische psychologie.
De minor wordt in het Nederlands aangeboden, maar de literatuur is Engelstalig.
Er wordt gewerkt in kleine teams. Studenten zijn van elkaars input en bijdragen afhankelijk. Daarom is aanwezigheid en actieve deelname verplicht.
Gedurende de wekelijkse bijeenkomsten krijgt de student feedback van de tutor. Dit kan betrekking hebben op studievoortgang en werkhouding en persoonlijke ontwikkeling (professioneel gedrag).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <div>Na afronding van deze minor heeft de student basale kennis van een aantal belangrijke psychologische theorieën uit de volgende subdisciplines:
Verder maakt de student kennis met verschillende vormen van psychologisch (wetenschappelijk) onderzoek.
Door de werkvorm van Probleem Gestuurd Onderwijs (PGO) leert de student:

column2: • In kleine groepen met studenten uit verschillende disciplines psychologische problemen te analyseren
• Uit deze probleemanalyse relevante (persoonlijke) leerdoelen te formuleren
• Nieuwe inzichten en kennis terug te koppelen in een multidisciplinair team

column1: De minor probeert de student aan te zetten om op basis van psychologische theorieën te reflecteren op zijn/haar persoonlijke en professionele ontwikkeling.

column1: In this course, students will look at financial decision-making from the perspective of households and individuals. With rising levels of debt and strained pension systems, there is a need to understand the financial decisions facing households and the way in which firms and policymakers can address these. The course also aims to provide insight into new areas of finance such as fintech which provide new challenges for regulators and opportunities for consumers.

The course aims to provide a framework that students can use to think about financial decision-making as well as apply this knowledge to socially relevant challenges, such as overindebtedness among economically vulnerable groups. In addition, the course investigates the importance of access to finance around the world and provides some examples of how companies (such as fintechs) are addressing consumer needs in new ways.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will be able to develop a framework for thinking about household financial decision-making
• Students will understand the role of financial products in improving consumer welfare and the financial instruments available to individuals and households
• Students will be able to use this framework to debate the merits of extending access to financial services (financial inclusion) as well regulation of financial services
• Students will be able to propose solutions on using technology to help providers of financial products improve consumer well-being
• Students will better understand the role of access to finance in improving (and worsening) consumer welfare
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We humans have an irresistible urge to explain our own and others’ behaviour, to attribute it to some causes and therefore, to make it seems orderly, predictable and controllable. Why do we behave, think, and feel as we do in social situations? How are our thoughts, feelings and behaviours shaped by others? How do we make sense of our social world and how do we become social? How do we see ourselves? These are the type of questions that the course Man & Society seeks to address. Obviously, a huge number of variables play a role in answering these questions and many disciplines employ scientific techniques to answer these questions. However, in this course we will try to answer these questions from a socio-psychological perspective and use quantitative research to investigate how and why certain (socio-psychological) behaviours occurred.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course deals with an important and relevant area of psychology, the social psychology. Social psychology is the scientific field that seeks to understand the nature and causes of individual behaviour in social situations. Social psychologists are interested in underlying social and cognitive processes as they are in overt behaviour. The central theme of social psychology is how people understand and interact with each other.
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Discuss the history and research methods of social psychology;
• Distinguish between cultures regarding the processes that underlie our thought, behaviour, and feelings in social situations;
• Apply theoretical concepts of this course in a more practical manner;
• Identify the components of the self and self-schemas;
• Define attitudes and how they develop and change;
• Explain the theories and dynamics of group formation: social categorization and social identity;
• Understand the antecedents and consequences of stereotyping, prejudice, racism, discrimination, and genocide;
• Describe evolutionary approaches to helping others and the bystander effect;
• Understand the way people attach meaning to other’s and their own behavior;
• Explain the theories of attraction and romantic relationships;
• Write a scientifically sound research paper on a particular subtopic from social psychology.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The study of anatomy (and morphology) is crucial in understanding how multiple tissue types and organ systems are organised in multicellular organisms, and how they interact. Moreover, it is not possible to understand how such organisms ‘work’ (as studied in physiology) without having fundamental anatomical knowledge. Clearly, this knowledge is also vital when studying the nature of a disease (pathology) as well as the biological mechanisms that lead to disease (pathogenesis).

In this course, we will focus on the anatomy of humans. You will learn the exact location, three-dimensional orientation and morphology of all major human body parts, and you will learn the correct anatomical language that is required to describe these parts. Particular attention will be given to the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and musculoskeletal systems. The course is designed in tight collaboration with the Erasmus MC, and consists of expert lectures, interactive tutorials, and dissection room practicals, which ensure that you will get a practical, hands-on learning experience.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • obtain a general understanding of the use and importance of general anatomical nomenclature (in Latin and/or English);
• learn to actively use the terms in the anatomy checklist to describe the basic anatomy of the bony skeleton and its joints;
• be able to relate the dermal and musculoskeletal system of the extremities to its nervous innervation;
• be able to explain how musculoskeletal system allows the movement and stability of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe the basic anatomy and functional properties of the anatomy of the thorax;
• learn how to describe the main characteristics of the human blood circulation and name the main arteries and veins of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe all the abdominal and pelvic organs and know where they are located in the abdominal and pelvic cavity, respectively;
• learn the basic functional anatomy of the human nervous system and head and neck structures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The first part of the course offers a systematic overview of the main subjects  and concepts of Philosophical Anthropology (such as the place of man in the Cosmos, the relationship between body and mind, consciousness, action, freedom of will, (inter)subjectivity, reflexivity and language), and its relationship to other philosophical disciplines, such as ethics and social philosophy, and the empirical sciences and humanities, which deal with human beings, such as biological anthropology, neuroscience, psychology, sociology, history, and cultural anthropology.

Next, we will distinguish the mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic conception of man and, inspired by Kant’s and Dilthey’s transcendental philosophy, we will analyze the third-person, second-person, and first person ontological perspectives connected to these conceptions. Against the background of the ‘Historization of the World View’, both in its naturalistic (Darwin) and hermeneutic (Dilthey) form, we will discuss Plessner’s philosophical anthropology as a still topical attempt to connect the two. Finally, against this background, will reflect on the possible futures of the human life form in the light of the so-called converging technologies (such as information technology, neuroscience, and biotechnology).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course the student understands and can use the key concepts of philosophical anthropology, is able to distinguish the differences between mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic approaches in the study of human nature, and has acquired a basic knowledge of the history and the possible futures of the human life from an evolutionary (Darwin), historical (Dilthey), and philosophical-anthropological (Plessner) perspective.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115894,2023,Human Conditions II,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. AW Prins'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this second part of ‘Human Conditions’ we will focus on Phenomenological & Hermeneutical approaches. Our point of departure will be the fortuitousness of western philosophy and the unsolved, but ever tentalising question, how we may comprehend the phenomenon of human existence while simultaniously being 'subject' and 'object' of this attempt toward comprehension ourselves.

Key figures in this course will be: Kierkegaard (on truth and individual existence), Husserl (on transcendental subjectivity as the ‘wonder of all wonders’), Heidegger (on the 'event' of being human and the framing of existence in the era of Technology), Sartre (the ontology of absolute freedom and radical responsibility), Merleau-Ponty (on the phenomenology of bodily perception), Gadamer (on philosophical hermeneutics) and Levinas (on questioning the primacy of ontology in phenomenology and western philosophy as a whole).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Understanding the historical predicaments of the ‘first-person perspective’ in Western Philosophy
2. Acquaintance with the main currents in the Phenomenological Movement and the ‘turn’ from Phenomenology to Hermeneutics
3. The ability to assess the importance, relevance and limitations of the philosophical positions presented and discussed during the course, and taking well-argued positions
4. Acknowledging the importance of, and being able to practice ‘stirring thinking’
5. The ability to thoroughly comprehend philosophical texts (academic skill training).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Human physiology studies how cells, tissues, organs and organ systems function in a healthy human body in response to internal and environmental changes. As a central concept in physiology, this course will highlight homeostatic processes, i.e. the maintenance of the steady state of the body within regulated ranges that are compatible with life. You will learn that homeostasis is regulated at multiple levels, from the cellular all the way to the organismal level. In this course, we will study the components and function of different physiological systems in the human body, including the cardiovascular system, circulatory system, respiratory system, musculoskeletal system, digestive system, urinary system, and the endocrine system. The human physiology will mainly be discussed under normal conditions, although pathologies and exceptional circumstances will be mentioned, such as high-altitude and space physiology. Importantly, this course aims to provide an integrated view of human physiology, acknowledging the complex interactions within and between different physiological systems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The physiology of systems under scrutiny include the integumentary system, the nervous system, the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, renal system, and the endocrine system. The immune system will be studied in detail in Quad 4, 200-level course, 'Micro- and immunobiology', and is therefore not a focus within this course.
Learning objectives regarding the biological systems under study include:

column2: • Be able to recognize different histological tissue samples from one another.
• Be able to describe the structure and identify characteristics of the organs’ tissues and relate them to their functioning.
• Understand how these vital parameters are regulated/ kept constant under normal and extraordinary circumstances (e.g., microgravity, high altitudes, cold temperatures).
• Be able to make and present a scientific poster in a clear and attractive way.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115280,2023,Human Resource Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. ME Schouten']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In many industries, the people – or the Human Resources – are the vital factors shaping success or failure for organizations. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, and retention (or dismissal!) of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains, losses, or potential legal implications for the organization, but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied.

This course offers you an evidence-based perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource Management (HRM). We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of HRM, including the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialisation process. Building on this, we deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and rewarding their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Finally, we will consider how to manage employees’ voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations.

By the end of the course, you will have a deep understanding of and basic hands-on experience with the most important HR practices in light of empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.  You will have learned to look beyond short-term financial gains for the organization when making decisions that affect people in organizations, but also have a thorough understanding of evidence-based guidelines on employee well-being, job satisfaction, and fairness. As a result, you are able to use your knowledge and skills about HRM to be a force for positive change for peoples’ working lives.

Given that HRM is a central organizational function, this course has links to many other courses in your curriculum. It particularly builds on your first-year course Organisational Behaviour, which laid the foundation for many of the concepts we will apply to workplace settings in this course and sets the stage for the third year specialism for People Experts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Explain fundamental HRM practices and their theoretical underpinnings.
Design solutions for HR-problems and cases by integrating theoretical knowledge and practical considerations.
Apply HR-related knowledge and skills to solve real-world organizational challenges in an international context.
Develop an evidence-based mindset in reflecting on the role of evidence in guiding the actions of people managers.</body>

column1: Human Resource Management (HRM) gaat er vanuit dat de mens een belangrijke bron is voor organisatiesucces en heeft daarom als doel het personeelsmanagement zo goed mogelijk te laten verlopen. Hoewel dit geldt voor HRM in alle organisaties, kent HRM in publieke organisaties een aantal specifieke uitdagingen en toepassingen.

In deze module wordt daarom ingegaan op actuele thema’s binnen HRM in de publieke sector zoals wendbaarheid, inclusiviteit, mobiliteit en werkgeluk. Deze thema’s hebben gemeenschappelijk dat ze hoog op de agenda van wetenschappers en beleidsmakers staan. In de hoorcolleges wordt dan ook gebruik gemaakt van actuele voorbeelden en recente literatuur.

De literatuur voor dit vak bestaat uit wetenschappelijke artikelen die via Canvas te verkrijgen zijn. Er wordt van u verwacht dat u voorafgaand aan het hoorcollege de aangewezen artikelen leest. Het is daarnaast mogelijk om voorafgaand aan ieder hoorcollege een individuele opdracht in te leveren. Door deze individuele opdrachten met een voldoende af te ronden kunt u 20% van het eindcijfer behalen, en hoeft u minder vragen te beantwoorden op het take-home tentamen.

column1: •   Beschrijven welke overeenkomsten en verschillen er tussen HRM in publieke en private organisaties zijn;
•   Toelichten welke actuele en toekomstige thema’s er op het gebied van HRM in de publieke sector spelen;
•   Beredeneren welke invloed HRM in een publieke organisatie heeft;
•   Uiteenzetten hoe HRM in de publieke sector kan worden toegepast.

column1: In de meeste sectoren is het effectief managen van personeel – Human Resource Management (HR/HRM) – een bepalende factor voor het succes of het falen van de organisatie. Beslissingen over werving, training, taakstelling, beloning en ontslag hebben namelijk verstrekkende gevolgen. Ze hebben niet alleen betrekking op het economisch welvaren van de organisatie of het juridisch kader, maar vooral ook op mensen en hun motivatie, welzijn en productiviteit.

Deze cursus biedt een evidence-based perspectief op de belangrijkste uitdagingen in Human Resource Management. We beginnen met het onderzoeken van de conceptuele basis van Human Resource Management, inclusief het ontwerp van banen en werkprocessen en de voorwaarden waaronder werk bevredigend en boeiend is. Vervolgens richten we ons op het wervingsproces, van de personeelsplanning tot het aannemen van nieuwe medewerkers en het starten van het socialisatieproces. Hierop voortbouwend hoe we prestaties meten, hoe bedrijven goede resultaten kunnen bereiken door hun personeel te motiveren en te betalen voor hun inspanningen en hoe de opleiding en de ontwikkeling voor huidige en toekomstige taken vorm kan krijgen. Ten slotte gaan we na hoe we het vrijwillig en onvrijwillig verlaten van organisaties door werknemers kunnen beheren.

Het is de bedoeling dat je aan het eind van dit vak theoretisch inzicht hebt verworven in de belangrijkste HRM-praktijken en ze tegelijk ook op hun praktijkwaarde kunt beoordelen. Je zult leren om verder te kijken dan financieel gewin voor de organisatie op korte termijn, bij het maken van beslissingen die van invloed zijn op de mensen in de organisatie. Ook doe je een grondig begrip op, van de evidence-based richtlijnen omtrent welzijn van medewerkers, baantevredenheid en eerlijkheid. Daardoor zal je je kennis en vaardigheden in HRM kunnen toepassen om positieve verandering te bewerkstelligen in het werkleven van mensen om je heen.

Omdat HRM een centrale functie binnen organisaties heeft, is het vanzelfsprekend dat je verbanden zal kunnen leggen met andere vakken in het curriculum. We denken daarbij in de eerste plaats aan het vak Gedrag in Organisaties dat de basis legt voor dit vak wat betreft de concepten en theorieën die essentieel zijn om effectief functioneren binnen organisaties te begrijpen. In dit vak diepen we dit verder uit en leggen we de basis voor de specialisatie Behavioural Experts in het derde jaar.

column1: There is a growing need for advanced information processes, which simultaneously address individual and societal requirements. For example, by integrating sources of personal information within personalized health services to provide targeted self-care guidance, and improve healthcare system efficiency. This is needed because complex, and rapidly growing, societal problems such as obesity, diabetes, infectious disease transmission, and harmful drug use cannot be solved by broad institutional measures alone. Broad population-level policies are slow to adapt, are disproportionate, and do not lead to lasting change.

This course seeks new ways to address complex behavioral problems by putting human needs at the center of information process development. Students will learn about digital technologies which may be used to ingest personal information and facilitate targeted behavioral interventions ant individual and societal levels. For example, technologies such as wearable biometric devices, environmental sensors, different forms of social media, machine learning / artificial intelligence, natural language processing, digital diagnostics, genomics, computer vision, drones, edge computing, digital twins, mobility pattern analysis, process analysis, process automation, and targeted messaging systems may all be combined to collect various forms of individual information, calculate personal risk exposures, and deliver targeted behavioral interventions.

Students will design human-centered processes by applying behavior change and social ecological theories together with business process modeling techniques. Within an iterative process, students will actively participate in class discussions, present their work, and receive feedback for improvement. Throughout the course, we will review relevant academic, and industrial, projects as inspirational case studies. Class participation is mandatory.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand technologies and methods which may facilitate human-centered processes
• Identify a complex behavioral problem and develop suitable interventions through the use of one or more digital technologies
• Recognize and include the role of the contextual environment in developing interventions
• Apply business process modeling techniques as a standard language to convey your project ideas
• Evaluate existing approaches and propose an improved process to guide individual and societal behavior

column1: The I DO Project is your opportunity, as a second year (I)BA student to become a Force for Positive Change. In this course, you will be placed in a team, and your team will be assigned a Non Governmental Organization (NGO) to work with throughout the entire year.

The NGOs you will work with all strive to make the world a better place by providing access to education, healthcare, food, water within their disenfranchised communities. They are all small organizations, often with a start-up like nature, making your position as consultants more valuable and challenging. They often lack processes and rely heavily on their founders for anything to happen. That is where you come in.
You will apply your theoretical knowledge and practical skills in providing your NGO consulting advice and implementing it, as you’ll turn abstract ideas into realities.

Your sole goal in this course is to maximize the positive social impact your NGO makes. Everything you will do will have to ultimately lead to this. The course itself and the examination are tailored towards assisting you in this process. You will be examined pragmatically on the extent to which you have successfully achieved this goal.

This is a practical course, where you will work with actual organizations, interacting with people who have financial, ideal and emotional stakes in them. You will not only give advice, but also apply it, and that will mean developing the necessary skills throughout the year. These range from Business Analysis to Web Design, from Communication and Presenting skills to Fundraising and Copywriting. You will implement work management software, and develop processes, you will analyze financials and evaluate impact.

More than anything, you will see what real world work looks like, with ill-defined tasks, problems, and a permanent feeling that you do not possess all the information you need to solve whatever issue you’ve identified. In the real world you don’t have the knowledge for everything you’re tasked to do, as the virtue of high-level work is the capacity to find that knowledge, to orient oneself through the mist of the undefined problem you are trying to solve.

This course is not for the faint of heart. It will challenge you and keep you in a state of discomfort and that is exactly why you will learn so much about Business, social impact, and yourselves while developing a myriad of skills that will assist you throughout your careers.

column1: Learning goals are connected to the Intended Learning Outcomes of the (I)BA program on knowledge, skills and attitudes. They reflect a pre-final mastery of these elements as defined by the Dublin Descriptors.

On the expert level student work will demonstrate analytical skills, and the skills of evaluating and creating/designing problem solutions by making use of prior learnings in their bachelors. Students show an ability to define and interpret the given problem based on the relevant societal, scientific and ethical aspects. Students show their ability to select the relevant information to underpin their analysis as well as their proposed solutions (Dublin 1, 2, 3).

On the level of attitude and skills development, students will be able to define their personal learning goals and gather documentation on their personal and professional development. They can communicate their findings to both stakeholders outside and inside RSM.
The learning goals are explicated in the section below.
Demonstrate knowledge of the economic, environmental and social impact of organizations on societies locally and globally.

Demonstrate the mastery of analytical skills while using quantitative and qualitative techniques to analyze business problems and design solutions for those problems using a scientific research approach.

column2: • The student identifies the challenge of an NGO in a close interaction with stakeholders to define a challenge that impacts the local environment the NGO operates in.
• The student applies specialist knowledge relating to his or her specific career track to design a solution that will affect economic, environmental and social impact.[1]

column1: Demonstrate the ability to work in diverse teams:

column2: • The student collaborates with all team members in order to incorporate their views on the problem definition; specific actions to be undertaken and the final design of the problem solution;
• The student evaluates and gives input to specific contributions of team members in order to enhance the quality of the product.
• The student proactively identifies and resolves issues that will both positively and/or negatively affect the team dynamics in order to enhance the team effort.[2]

column1: Demonstrate the mastery of life-long learning skills to challenge one’s own limitations, recognize opportunities for learning, acquire new knowledge, and undertake further study with a high degree of autonomy.

column2: • The student underpins the choice for the NGO-challenge and the team role based upon his or her own personal qualities and competencies in order to contribute to the product (create positive impact).
• The student formulates a personal challenge, personal learning goals and further goals for development in line with the challenge of the NGO, team competencies and multiple perspective feedback.

column1: Demonstrate a mind-set of working according to principles of trust and integrity, make the values of a multicultural and international orientation the basis of their view of people and society, and accept corporate social responsibility and sustainability as values.

column2: • The student gathers proof of personal integrity and inclusivity with stakeholders outside the project group in order to evaluate personal values.[3]

column1: [1] In order to evaluate ILO 3, we would like the student to be able to assess their outcome of its work with the NGO in terms of impact. However, the student should not only think of its direct impact on the NGO and its beneficiaries but should also consider their “indirect” impact (e.g., the impact on the local environment the NGO operates in).

[2] In order to evaluate ILO 6, we would like the student to be able to collaborate effectively within its team. As such, the student should show effort and motivation to excel and improve teamwork. Furthermore, he should also be able to proactively prevent any internal team issues and solve internal conflicts if needed.

[3] In order to evaluate ILO 7, we would like the student to show honesty and integrity during their work with their NGO, but also internally with their teammates and coaches. Furthermore, the student should always be able to pick the right decision aligned with the I DO project and NGO values.

column1: The first two decades of the 21st century have witnessed a considerable reduction of poverty and associated phenomena in countries previously labeled as “under-developed” countries. The rapid and widespread innovations, mostly enabled and  driven  by  Information  and  Communication Technologies (ICTs), have given rise to “Emerging Markets”, also known as “Emerging Economies”. More and more developing countries are making remarkable inroads into economic growth and some have even become global leaders in specific areas. The introduction of the Internet, followed by the advent of mobile telephony, has been instrumental in driving innovation in vital sectors such as education, healthcare, economic livelihood, and local entrepreneurship, to mention a few areas. ICT and Innovation scholars project not only more ICT-driven innovations in emerging markets, but also the transfer from those innovations into developed countries (reverse innovation).

This seminar offers students a critical, analytical, historical, and practical insight into the various ways in which Emerging Markets have been taking advantage of the development process to become central to the ICT-driven innovations. Students historically explores the transition from the previous approach, one that was mostly centred on international development policies, to the current home- grown, ICT-driven innovation approach to poverty alleviation. In this seminar, students get an insight into real-life ICT-driven innovations that involve various actors (e.g., local startups, NGOs, governments, multinationals) and in different areas and sectors. The seminar focuses on the following key areas: education (in the broader sense), healthcare, rural entrepreneurship (income- generating activities), economic livelihood, and banking (and related services). While exploring these areas, students are invited to go beyond the surface (the hype) to critically consider underlying concepts such as power, gender, sustainability, inclusiveness, and ethics.

column1: Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
* The range and usage of ICTs in communication for social development and profit
* The history and politics of ICT use in emerging economies
* The workings of real time based ICTD projects in emerging economies and the range of challenges with the market, the state and the public intersecting
* Think strategically on real time public-private sector communicative approaches to contemporary issues involving ICT in education, politics, healthcare, and entrepreneurship
* Think critically on social and public policy
* Obtain information from/communicate with private sector professionals in the ICT4D (ICT for development) field in emerging markets

column1: The Research Clinic constitutes the formal start of the MSc International Management thesis semester. The seminar informs IM students about the following research issues:

column2: • How does one write an interesting and persuasive thesis?
• How does one formulate a challenging research question?
• What is an adequate research methodology to answer the central research question?

column1: Pre-requisites: Students must have completed the full first year of the MSc International Management/CEMS programme in order to advance to the research clinic and thesis semester.

Course structure: The Research Clinic is structured around four plenary lectures that address the research issues stated above; in parallel, students work in small-scale highly interactive work groups applying these themes to their own research topic. Groups will typically consist of students sharing similar research topics. The output of this seminar is a research proposal for the Master thesis.

All plenary sessions are interactive; students can expect to be asked questions, to make presentations, or to engage in discussion with other fellow students. The preceding implies that students are expected to come to class prepared, having carefully read all the compulsory literature and submitted the assignments.

In addition to the plenary sessions, students have three work-group sessions with their supervisor. These sessions focus on the actual writing of the research proposal. Depending on the supervisor these sessions will be run in groups or individually.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To enhance the student’s understanding of the process and methods of international business and management research.
• To assist students in applying this knowledge and methodology to their own research project.

column1: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to:

column2: • construct an interesting story and write a persuasive thesis (proposal)
• craft an interesting and relevant research question
• select an appropriate research methodology to answer a specific research question
• construct and plan the design and execution of a study

column1: The Ian Fletcher International Insolvency Moot is the most prestigious moot competition in the field of international insolvency law in the world. Even though the competition is still relatively young (the first competition was organised in 2017), it has already gained a significant international reputation. In the words of the organisers:

“The Fletcher Moot encourages the best and brightest students around the globe to learn about international insolvency law and international commercial litigation. The competition is dedicated to raising the profile of insolvency and restructuring within the university curriculum.

Students will have a chance to engage with their peers, judges and members of international insolvency bodies. It also provides an avenue for academics, judges and a diverse range of insolvency experts to collaborate in mentoring the next generation of lawyers.
The Fletcher Moot is coordinated by Professor Adrian Walters (Chicago-Kent College of Law, red.), and Jelena Wenlock is the Moot Registrar.”

Last academic year, the competition attracted a record number of 28 registrations from law schools across the world. This is a similar number to comparable moot courts in a niche field of law, such as the International Maritime Law & Arbitration Moot, and the PAX Moot.

Comparable as well to other moot courts, the Fletcher Moot consists of two parts: written submissions for both claimant and respondent, followed by pleading sessions directly against other universities. The teams are evaluated on both these aspects separately. Previous winners of the written aspect of the competition include the National Law University (India), Leiden University, the University of Queensland (Australia), and the National University of Singapore. Previous winners of the oral pleadings include the University of British Columbia (Canada), Singapore Management University (twice), and the National Law University (India).

The venue of the pleading sessions is different every year. The pleadings have been organised by the Queensland University of Technology in Sydney and in London, by the University pf British Columbia in Vancouver, and by Singapore Management University in Singapore. Both Leiden University and Radboud University have represented the Netherlands in previous editions of the Fletcher Moot.

A university team consists of two to maximum four students, and they may be supervised by a maximum of two coaches. Teams are evaluated in four categories: legal analysis, research, argument, and style. Competing students must resolve the moot problem based on the Model Laws on Insolvency created by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL). These are most notably the UNCITRAL Model Law on Cross-border Insolvency (1997) and the UNCITRAL Model Law on Enterprise Group Insolvency (2019). These instruments have been determinative in unifying the field of international insolvency across all continents and they are leading in the academic debate on this topic.

The competition is supported by the two largest international associations for insolvency practice: the III (International Insolvency Institute) and INSOL International (International Association of Restructuring, Insolvency & Bankruptcy Professionals).

Finally, the name giver of the competition, Professor Ian Fletcher, is internationally recognised for his outstanding achievements in the field of insolvency law. In 2013, he was the first academic to be awarded the highly prestigious INSOL Scroll of Honour. Sadly, Professor Fletcher passed away in 2018.
Following government measures in the wake of the covid-19 pandemic, the entire 2021 competition will take place virtually.

The moot problem has already been released on 11 September 2020. Registrations for the competition close on 16 October. Subsequently, on 6 November the deadline for written submissions is scheduled. Teams are informed of their acceptance to the oral rounds in December. Finally, the oral rounds will take place in March 2021, with the grand final scheduled provisionally on 20 March 2021.

In conclusion, the Fletcher Moot is an exceptional opportunity for students, studying a Commercial Law or Private Law master, who want to deepen their knowledge on international insolvency law. At the same time, this competition uniquely prepares students for legal practice by simulating a real-case scenario. Especially in times of economic turmoil, like nowadays, educating excellent insolvency law practitioners is essential. Few better opportunities than the Ian Fletcher International Insolvency Moot exist to do so.

column1: Today’s culture is a visual culture. Since the 1970s, the social sciences and the humanities have increasingly turned their attention to the many ways in which visual technologies and images have come to play a central role in the construction of the shared meanings, or mental representations, through which our social practices are structured. Images reproduce power relations as much as they can contest dominant ways of seeing, and thinking about, the world. In this course we will analyse representations of class, gender, race and sexuality that circulate in the media by discussing and applying various key texts and methodologies from the fields of media studies and cultural analysis. Students read foundational texts by authors such as Roland Barthes, Stuart Hall, and Laura Mulvey and apply various visual methodologies in order to analyse a self-selected set of images in our weekly workshop.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: You cannot understand philosophy without learning to philosophise yourself, that is, at least Kant’s view and his whole philosophical project is to provide us with the tools to do so. This course explores the critical framework within which this revolution in philosophy operates, starting with Kant’s analysis of what makes reason rational, capable of distinguishing between self-illusion, which leads to the frustrations of scepticism, and its own proper, reliable functions.

We shall look at how Kant builds a form of empiricism based on purely rational capacities shared by all human beings, which both limit our pretentions to knowledge of the world and at the same time empower us to act freely in a world we know we do not know as it really is.

If these capacities are limited by the way the human mind works, these capacities are such that we project ends for ourselves onto the world even when we know full well we do not know all there is to know about it. The greatest projection of all is our own freedom to project such ends. We shall examine the theory of freedom and the duties that we are bound to fulfil in the name of this freedom, following the injunctions of the Moral Law within us. The categorical imperative, we shall see, is thus bound to an inalienable moral conscience.

How to reconcile the sense of our freedom with the knowledge that the world out there, nature, is unknowable to us? The question comes down to reconciling the theorist in us who has acquired knowledge through our subjective experience, with the moral citizens we also are - people who act according to our inalienable sense of freedom. Though we know the world as it is, distinct from our experience, is unknowable, we cannot not project an end, a finality to nature. We shall see how this projection, which can only, in fact, originate from our own judgement, enables us to act in the world as if the world were adapted to us and was in fact meant for us to realise our freedom. This is Kant’s teleological judgement, which we shall see draws a bridge between action and aesthetics, and also plays a role in his anthropological and political thought.

column1: Does increasing legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does development aid raise economic growth? Do changes in schooling laws improve health? The answer to any of these questions requires valid methods to evaluate the impact of different interventions.

The objective of this course is to provide students with a set of theoretical and practical skills that will allow them to evaluate the causal impact of different policy interventions and social programs. The course will introduce students to a variety of econometric methods in impact evaluation and a set of reasoning skills to help them design an evaluation study and assess critically existing studies. Students will get hands‑on experience with applying the techniques in Stata.
At the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and apply a variety of impact evaluation methods
• Critically analyse impact evaluation research
• Draw policy implications from impact evaluation research

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112151,2023,Impact Evaluation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. JLW van Kippersluis'],,Inhoud

Does a university degree raise your future wage? Does increasing the legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does restricting the bonuses of portfolio managers lead to less risk taking? Does development aid raise economic growth? Answering such questions requires a valid method of evaluating the effect of interventions.

In medicine one patient group is randomly assigned to a treatment while others receive a placebo. Identifying the effect of treatment is then relatively straightforward. In business, economics and social policy, such randomized experiments are often infeasible, unaffordable or considered unethical. Statistical methods must then be used to estimate the effect of an intervention relative to a counterfactual. This often calls for a great deal of creativity on the part of the analyst.

This course will give a non-technical overview of the intuition behind the most frequently applied evaluation methods in economics. The students will learn the required steps in a valid evaluation, the distinction between correlation and causal effects, the assumptions of different methods and in which situation each method can be used.

The main concepts are introduced in the first five weeks. The second part of the course is devoted to a group assignment, which will consist of a critical assessment of an existing evaluation, providing suggestions for improvement, and implementing these suggestions yourself. The students will hand-in a written report.

• Describe the difference between a correlation and a causal effect using the Potential Outcomes Framework.
• Critically assess an existing policy evaluation/academic paper that aims to estimate causal effects.
• Determine which Impact Evaluation method is best suited to study a research question.

• Estimate causal effects using statistical software for the most often applied Impact Evaluation techniques (multiple regression, matching, fixed effects, difference-in-difference, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity).
• Work in a team to successfully complete a group assignment.
