column1: De afgelopen jaren is het internationaal strafrecht zowel in omvang als betekenis toegenomen. Dit is grotendeels het gevolg van de ‘globalisering’ en daarmee ook van het (straf)recht. Er zal worden ingegaan op de traditionele instrumenten van het internationaal strafrecht: rechtsmacht, de uitlevering, de overdracht en overname van strafvervolging, de overdracht en tenuitvoerlegging van strafvonnissen en de kleine rechtshulp in strafzaken (politiële en justitiële rechtshulp). Daarnaast zal bijzondere aandacht worden geschonken aan het internationale strafrecht binnen de Europese Unie door middel van het Europees Arrestatiebevel en het Europees Onderzoeksbevel alsmede aan overige ontwikkelingen in de Europese rechtsruimte. Tevens zullen ontwikkelingen in de strafrechtelijke afdoening van internationale misdrijven worden besproken.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het verschaffen en vergroten van inzicht in de manieren waarop landen met elkaar samenwerken bij de toepassing van strafrecht. Daarbij wordt tevens kennis van basisstructuren van strafrechtsplegingen in Europa bevorderd. De volgende leerdoelen staan centraal:
1. Het analyseren van de theoretische achtergronden, historische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke aspecten van het internationale en Europese strafrecht;
2. Het verkrijgen van inzicht in de verschillende bronnen en grondslagen van internationaal en Europees (straf)recht;
3. Het beoordelen aan welk land in een concreet geval rechtsmacht toekomt en hoe omgegaan moet worden met conflicten dienaangaande;

4. Het toepassen van het raamwerk van instrumenten voor de strafrechtelijke samenwerking binnen de EU (kleine rechtshulp, overlevering, overdracht van strafvervolging en overdracht van de tenuitvoerlegging van straffen) op basis van het beginsel van wederzijdse erkenning op een concreet geval
5. Het evalueren wat de harmonisatie van het materieel strafrecht en het formeel strafrecht betekent voor het nationale recht van de EU-lidstaten;
6. Het evalueren van de doorwerking van het EU-recht door de rechtspraak van het Hof van Justitie van de EU;

7. Het toepassen van de regelgeving van de verschillende vormen van strafrechtelijke samenwerking (kleine rechtshulp, uitlevering, overdracht van strafvervolging en overdracht van de tenuitvoerlegging van straffen), ook buiten de EU, in een concreet geval
8. Het analyseren van het nationale en internationale recht inzake de opsporing, vervolging en berechting van internationale misdrijven en dat in een concreet geval toepassen

9. Het analyseren van een concrete casus waarbij ook horizontale verbanden (tussen verschillende deelonderwerpen van het vak) gelegd kunnen worden, het kritisch kunnen reflecteren op een antwoord van een medestudent en dit zowel mondeling als schriftelijk kunnen verwoorden.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114376,2023,Internationaal privaatrecht voor ondernemingsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.dr. FJM De Ly'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Ondernemen is voor de Nederlandse praktijk bijna in wezen grensoverschrijdend. In dit vak wordt deze internationale dimensie voor het voetlicht gebracht. Is Boek 2 bijvoorbeeld altijd toepasselijk in grensoverschrijdende gevallen? Is de Nederlandse rechter wel bevoegd voor grensoverschrijdende gevallen van massaschade? Worden contracten altijd beheerst door Nederlands recht? Wanneer kunnen internationale geschillen door arbitrage beslecht worden? Wat is de rol van EU recht bij de oplossing van deze problemen? Wat is de functie van eenvormig privaatrecht (bijv. EU Richtlijnen, Weens Koopverdrag) bij grensoverschrijdende gevallen?

Het Internationaal privaatrecht omvat daarbij het samenstel van regels die privaatrechtelijke rechtsverhoudingen met internationale elementen bestrijken. Het gaat daarbij in het bijzonder om de vraag van het toepasselijke recht, de vraag naar de bevoegdheid van de rechter en of buitenlandse vonnissen in Nederland geëxecuteerd kunnen worden.

Tijdens het hoorcollege worden de algemene leerstukken en begrippen van het IPR besproken, zulks aan de hand van jurisprudentie en gevallen uit de praktijk. Door toepassing van de theorie op praktijkgevallen wordt tegelijkertijd inzicht verworven op het terrein van IPR-vragen bij zakenrecht, verbintenissenrecht, rechtspersonenrecht, burgerlijk procesrecht en arbitragerecht. De casuscolleges stellen de studenten in de gelegenheid enige vaardigheid te verwerven in het oplossen van casusposities op het terrein van het IPR aan de hand van de schriftelijke opgaven, die in de syllabus zijn afgedrukt.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na afloop van dit vak kan de student:

column2: • De verschillende rechtsregels die behoren tot het IPR op nationaal, Europees en internationaal niveau toepassen op internationale commerciële geschillen.
• IPR-uitspraken afkomstig van de Nederlandse rechter en het Europese Hof van Justitie kritisch becommentariëren en gebruiken bij het oplossen van internationale geschillen uit de praktijk.
• De juridische methodologie van het internationaal privaatrecht begrijpen en de drie hoofdvragen uit het IPR onderscheiden en beantwoorden.
• De diverse bronnen van het Nederlandse IPR en van internationale organisaties die zich inspannen voor harmonisering van IPR-regelgeving, raadplegen.
• De werking van het IPR in de praktijk toelichten en het belang van regelgeving in het IPR aangeven.
• Het IPR in bredere verbanden, zoals het Nederlandse IPR met het IPR van andere landen en het IPR in de context van de mondialisering van het recht, onderkennen en analyseren.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114132,2023,Internationaal privaatrecht voor privaatjuristen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.dr. FJM De Ly'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Door de toename van het internationale handels- en rechtsverkeer wordt het internationaal privaatrecht (IPR) steeds belangrijker. Het IPR omvat het samenstel van regels die privaatrechtelijke rechtsverhoudingen met internationale elementen bestrijken. Het gaat daarbij in het bijzonder om de vraag van het toepasselijke recht, de vraag naar de bevoegdheid van de rechter en de vraag naar grensoverschrijdende erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging van vonnissen. Welk recht is bijvoorbeeld van toepassing op een arbeidsovereenkomst tussen een Nederlandse werkgever en een in Frankrijk wonende werknemer? Welke rechter is bevoegd ten aanzien van een loonvordering van de werknemer tegen de werkgever? Kan een door de Franse rechter gewezen veroordelend vonnis in Nederland ten uitvoer worden gelegd? Op familierechtelijk terrein duiken gelijkaardige vragen op. Welk recht is bijvoorbeeld van toepassing op het huwelijksgoederenregime van een Belgische man die in 1989 in Frankrijk met een Nederlandse vrouw is gehuwd? En kan een door de Spaanse rechter uitgesproken echtscheiding in Nederland worden erkend?

Tijdens het hoorcollege wordt een aantal algemene leerstukken en begrippen van het IPR besproken aan de hand van jurisprudentie en gevallen uit de praktijk. Door toepassing van de theorie op praktijkgevallen wordt tegelijkertijd inzicht verworven op het terrein van IPR-vragen bij personenrecht, zakenrecht, erfrecht en huwelijksgoederenrecht, verbintenissenrecht, rechtspersonenrecht, insolventierecht en burgerlijk procesrecht.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
De student is na afloop van dit vak in staat tot het:

column2: • analyseren, interpreteren en oplossen van casusposities op het gebied van het internationaal privaatrecht, in het bijzonder: (a) internationale arbitrage (b) onderneming- en insolventierechtelijke vraagstukken alsmede (d) internationaal personen-, familie- en erfrecht;
• onderscheiden en beantwoorden van de drie hoofdvragen van het IPR (bevoegdheid, toepasselijk recht en erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging);
• begrijpen van de juridische methodologie van het internationaal privaatrecht;
• toepassen van de relevante nationale, Europese en internationale IPR-regels;

• kritisch becommentariëren van IPR-uitspraken afkomstig van de Nederlandse rechter en het Europese Hof van Justitie en het gebruiken van deze uitspraken bij het oplossen van internationale geschillen uit de praktijk;
• begrijpen hoe de werking van het IPR is in de praktijk;
• begrijpen van het belang van regelgeving in het IPR;
• duiden van actuele ontwikkelingen op het gebied van IPR-wetgeving en –rechtspraak;
• onderkennen en analyseren van het IPR in bredere verbanden, zoals het Nederlandse IPR met het IPR van andere landen en het IPR in de context van de mondialisering van het recht.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114658,2023,International Art Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. FRR Vermeylen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The course will provide an in-depth discussion on international art markets, and will outline the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution, consumption and valuation of different art forms will be discussed: price-setting mechanisms, segmentation of the art market, globalization of the art trade, the role of intermediaries and galleries, art as investment, etc. Special attention will be devoted to emerging art markets, and how they are impacting the international art market system. The seminars provide a guide to the subject matter and set out foundations on which students can build. The weekly class meetings depend on active participation by the students and provide the opportunity for in-depth discussion of key issues and optional topics from which the students can choose according to their own interests.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will confront master students with current research in the functioning of modern art markets. Students will be exposed to recent theoretical insights and research methods particularly drawing from the field of cultural economics. We will discuss relevant literature on the various subjects through lectures, student presentations and class discussion. Finally, the participants will focus on one topic and carry out individual research based on scholarly literature and (on-line) databases such as artprice.com, resulting in a final essay.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116088,2023,International Business,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. AC Brown'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to introduce students to theories of international business as part of the Global Thinkers track and is the first of three interrelated courses. The course will cover topics relating with international business theory, ownership structure, IPOs, institutional investor, regulatory reforms, stakeholder involvement and corporate social responsibility. Some of the theory included are Agency theory; Transaction costs economics; Stakeholder theory; Stewardship theory; Institutional theory; Political theory as well as Network governance and case studies/ examples real life corporate stories.
The course will include lectures combining theory, cases and live examples including a project, for students to analyze, discuss and present on during seminar sessions and workshops.

Students will be expected to be active participants in exploring real instances of effect of governance issues on actual entrepreneurial firms of all sizes but with particular attention to smaller and family enterprises.

Students will be encouraged to make use of provided articles, case studies but also to explore themes and topics by accessing news sites, databases and public informational depositories in a guided but self-proactive environment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The ability to critically reflect on and provide well-grounded analysis of these elements crucial for both Multinationals and Regionationals, as well as small firms who are starting to internationalize
• The ability to analyse the main elements of International Business theories
• Has the ability to demonstrate the value and impact of models in the firm’s ability to internationalize successfully
• Construct IB frameworks, considering alternatives and assessing these
• Discuss the different theories and their pluses and minuses within an emerging market context
• Discuss expansion frameworks, considering alternatives and assessing these within an institutional context
• Evaluate business risks and opportunities for growth, reflecting on the potential for contributing to success

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114683,2023,International Business and Nation-states,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AF Heslinga', 'LN Remij, MA', 'prof.dr. B Wubs']",,"Inhoud

<body>Multinationals and their role in the process of globalization have attracted a great deal of attention from business historians. The origins of modern multinationals, and consequently foreign direct investment (FDI), lay in the second half of the nineteenth century, although the Dutch East India Company (VOC), set up in 1602, is often considered to be the first multinational. However, the    growth of large scale, mainly industrial multinationals, concurred with the emergence of the first   liberal global economy. Trade protectionism, which represented a partial departure from liberalism, served to stimulate multinational manufacturing as well, because companies opened factories in protected markets. World War I was a turning point in the development of a global economy and the end of free trade. Yet multinationals continued to operate abroad and even expanded during the 1920s and 1930s. After World War II, multinationals began to play a key role in the world economy. As multinationals by definition operate in at least two different nations they necessarily have to deal at least with two different governments. Because of this interaction, there may be conflict or cooperation between multinationals and host and home governments. This course focuses on the ever-changing relations between multinationals and national governments from the  seventeenth century to the present.</body>

column1: The course will discuss the arbitral process starting from the agreement to arbitrate to the challenge and enforcement of arbitral awards.

Students taking this class will already have a clear understanding and sufficient initial command of the fundamental concepts of arbitration law (e.g., why do parties arbitrate, advantages and disadvantages of arbitration, types of arbitration (i.e., ad hoc and institutional), arbitrability, the arbitration agreement, the different laws and rules that are relevant in an arbitration proceeding, etc.), as studied in the Fundamentals of International Arbitration course during Block 2. Therefore, the course will build upon that knowledge and cover both procedural and substantive aspects of the arbitral process and the study of the relevant applicable laws and rules.

During this course, the main concepts of arbitration law, relevant current issues and different procedural steps in an arbitration proceeding (e.g., commencing the arbitration, constitution of the tribunal, request for interim measures, taking of evidence, the evidentiary hearing, the making of the award, cost allocation, etc.) will be analysed in more detail and from a comparative law perspective. The most important instruments that come into play during an international arbitral proceeding will be studied further. For example, the different applicable laws, conventions and rules (e.g., the UNCITRAL Model Law, the New York Convention, the IBA Guidelines on Conflicts of Interest, the IBA Rules on the Taking of Evidence, etc.) and the different arbitration rules (such as the UNCITRAL, ICC, LCIA and NAI arbitration rules) will be discussed, with an emphasis on a comparative and critical analysis of the relevant instruments.

During the course, students will examine and compare different approaches seen in different jurisdictions, and/or provided by different institutions, in relation to similar issues and procedures in international arbitration (e.g., commencement of arbitral proceedings, appointment and challenges of arbitrators, interim measures and emergency arbitration procedures, the conduct of the proceedings, annulment of arbitral awards, etc.).

Students will be encouraged and expected to actively participate and provide their input and analysis based on the regulation of, and approach to, different issues and concepts in their own home jurisdictions. Students will also actively participate in the discussions by making presentations on specific issues and working on practical assignments where the issues debated in class will be applied to practical scenarios.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Familiarize students with and give them in-depth knowledge of arbitration law and practice from an international and comparative law perspective. After the course, the students will be able to:

column2: • Critically assess the different concepts in international arbitration.

• Compare and understand the differences between, and the pros and cons of, the various instruments widely used in international arbitration (e.g., different institutional rules, different arbitration acts).
• Understand the practical side of, and the relevant considerations when running, an international arbitration proceeding.
• Understand and critically assess the relevant recent case law and latest developments in international arbitration.
• Understand how an arbitral proceeding is run and what a young arbitration practitioner should and should not do.
• Provide well-founded advice in relation complex questions, both of theoretical and practical nature, in relation to international arbitration law and proceedings.

column1: This course teaches a general management perspective on financial decision making and provides participants with the skills and knowledge to increase the value of a corporation. The course should appeal to participants who want to work as finance executives within a corporation, consultants, investment bankers, private equity, or venture capital investors. The course is also suited for participants who simply want to extend their finance knowledge.

The aim of this course is to teach participants the knowledge and skills that a manager needs for good investment, financing, and operating decisions at internationally operating corporations. The first part of the course will review basic financial concepts relevant for managers and discusses corporate risk management. The second part introduces financial tools to manage risks within an international corporation, teaches macro-economic financial theory, and enables course participants to understand and measure different types of risks within a corporation.

The course is highly interactive and employs a variety of didactic formats, including lectures, case studies, and in-class exercises. As the focus of the course is on the application of financial theory, the course is suitable for participants with or without a background in finance.

The course is designed as an interactive learning experience. Experience from past years shows that attendance during the lectures greatly increases the learning benefit. For this reason, all participants are strongly encouraged to be present in all meetings.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Discuss whether companies should (not) engage in risk management
• Judge risk exposures arising in different business models

column1: This course examines corporate governance practices from an international and multidisciplinary perspective. Corporate governance deals with the mechanisms through which control is exercised over corporate managers. How do suppliers of finance (i.e. shareholders) make sure that managers do the right thing and do not steal the capital or invest the capital in bad projects? During this course the main topics of corporate governance will be discussed. The focus is on legal aspects of corporate governance. Among the topics to be discussed are:
- The definition of corporate governance; the separation between ownership and control; Agency costs theory;
- The functioning of boards of directors; the role of outside directors and one tier and two tier boards;
- The role of executive compensation and the market for corporate control (hostile takeovers);
- Shareholder rights, shareholder activism and shareholder litigation;
- Corporate governance codes; securities regulations; monitoring by state agencies;
- Comparative corporate governance: developments towards convergence especially between the US and the EU.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the significance of corporate governance issues
• Understand the way corporate governance issues are regulated
• Value the rights and responsibilities of both shareholders and the board of directors
• Understand the significance of internal and external monitoring
• Independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning international corporate governance, including questions concerning regulation, board structure, takeovers and remuneration

column1: Work in a team in order to analyze critically on how the current legal framework, relevant to the fields of international corporate governance operates and evolves and to provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own</body>

column1: <body>The International Criminal Law course will provide students with the necessary knowledge to analyse past and current situations of crisis in order to determine whether core international crimes have been committed and what are the different mechanisms to bring the responsible to justice. The course examines the historical and legal developments in the different fields of international public law that brought about the creation of the International Criminal Court (ICC) and the different international and hybrid mechanisms of criminal justice conceived afterwards. It will then focus on the ICC’s jurisdictional parameters and triggering proceedings to later analyse in detail, discussing real current and past cases before the ICC, the different judicial proceedings before the Court, from preliminary to trial, appeal, and reparations proceedings.</body>

column1: The course outline will set out the chapters that provide relevant background information for particular topics. For each class, additional reading materials will be prescribed to introduce the students to the scholarly work on different topics and relevant case law.

Students should have in their possession the most recent version of the ICC Statute and ‘Elements of Crimes’ (on the basis of article 9 ICC statute) and have it handy during lectures and group work sessions, as well as during the exam.
A good source which includes the main ICL documents, including the above, is, Cryer, Robert, ed. International criminal law documents. Cambridge University Press, 2019.
In addition to the textbook, students may always resort to supplementary literature, for example

column2: • Stahn, Carsten. A critical introduction to international criminal law. Cambridge University Press, 2019.
• Cassese & P. Gaeta, Cassese’s International Criminal Law (Oxford University Press, 3rd edition, 2013) or
• W. Schabas, An Introduction to the International Criminal Court (New York, Cambridge University Press, 4th edition, 2011).
• Kai Ambos, Treatise on International Criminal Law, 3 vols. (OUP 2013, 2014, 2016).
• Triffterer, Otto. Commentary on the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. Baden-Baden: Nomos (1999).

• An interesting recent book presenting a different view on the International Criminal Justice is by Christine Schwöbel-Patel, Marketing Global Justice: The Political Economy of International Criminal Law, Cambridge Studies in International and Comparative Law, Series Number 151 (Cambridge University Press, 2021)

column1: The course aims to introduce students to the field of international criminal law, its unique features; development; institutions and procedures. Within the framework of the regime of international criminal law various international criminal courts and tribunals have been established in order to assess individual criminal responsibility at the international level, including the International Criminal Court, International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia and the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. Attention is paid to the jurisdiction and procedure of these international tribunals, as well as to the definition of the four core crimes, namely aggression, genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity, and the distinctive modes of liability.

column2: • The student will be able to independently describe, analyse and assess the essential principles governing international criminal law as well as the various bodies and procedures through which international criminal law is being institutionalized;
• The student will be able to independently apply the essential substantive and procedural principles of international criminal law to hypothetical cases and deliver well founded legal advice; and
• The student will be able to independently conduct academic research relevant to international criminal law and based on this, provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will examine international dispute settlement in more depth, and with emphasis on inter-state judicial institutions, such as the International Court of Justice, and state/on-state dispute settlement. The opening lectures will address themes such as the concept of “international dispute”, the obligation to resolve disputes peacefully, the matrix of available dispute settlement options and the role and specificity of judicial dispute settlement mechanisms. Subsequent lectures will be devoted to the norms of “international legal procedure” governing international tribunals, with a focus on the International Court of Justice. The remaining lectures will turn their attention to the examination of specific judicial institutions, cross-cutting issues such as the independence and selection of judges and arbitrators, the role of the current dispute settlement “architecture”. Specific institutions which will be discussed include ITLOS, the WTO DS system and other mixed dispute settlement bodies, such as ICSID.

column1: Why are some rich, while others remain poor? How have international trade, states, institutions, and (human) capital flows affected economic growth? These are some of the key questions that economic history deals with. Since 1500 the world has seen a wide variety of economic developments, such as industrialization, imperialism and colonialism, waves of globalization and deglobalization, and the rise and fall of economic centers. Transportation and communication technologies have created a smaller world with a higher level of economic interdependence.

These developments have had profound impacts on the economic development of regions around the world. Apart from war and treaties, the field of international relations also includes this economic dimension through trade, investment and other monetary relations. This course focuses on international trade and the development of international monetary systems. Furthermore, economic policies have varied over time, ranging from mercantilist power politics to international economic collaboration and from free trade to protectionism. This course addresses the questions that underpin global economic history and introduces theories from the field of international relations, including Realism, Liberalism, Constructivism, English School, Marxism, and Neoliberal Institutionalism.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Differentiate the most important international relations theories (Realism, Liberalism, Constructivism, the English School, Marxism, and Neoliberal Institutionalism).
• Apply the most important international relations theories to historical cases of international economic relations.
• Describe the economic development for the ten regions discussed in the handbook.
• Differentiate at least three theories that explain the different economic development between rich and poor nations.
• Explain three different international monetary systems and how these affected national economic policies.
• Explain the advantages and disadvantages of using economic growth as a measure of prosperity and well-being.
• Describe how periods of protectionism and free trade alternated throughout history.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: International economics deals with issues raised by the interactions between countries. It can be divided into two broad fields: international trade and open-economy macroeconomics. The first deals with the real side of international economic relations, i.e. the exchange of goods and services, and answers questions like: Why do countries trade? What do they trade? What are the consequences of trade? How is it regulated by policy? The second deals with the monetary side of the international economy, i.e. the exchange of assets, and focuses in particular on how the exchange rate between two currencies is determined.

Although macroeconomic quantities are at the core of the analysis, a microeconomic perspective is also often employed. Furthermore, the nature of the subject implies that international economists frequently find inspiration elsewhere for their applications, for example from geography, econometrics, development economics, monetary economics, industrial organisation, etc. This approach results in a rich diversity of insights, nonetheless characterised by a remarkable coherence.

column1: The course international economics focuses primarily on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international trade, capital flows, economic growth, exchange rates and financial crises. Although macroeconomic quantities are at the core of the analysis, these will usually be built up from a microeconomics perspective. The nature of the analysis implies that international economists frequently find inspiration elsewhere for their applications, for example from economic geography, monetary economics, econometrics, development economics or industrial organization. This approach results in a rich diversity of insights, nonetheless characterized by a remarkable coherence.

column1: Instructors: Prof. F.J.G.M. Klaassen (UvA), Dr J. Emami Namini (EUR) and Prof. M. Bosker (EUR)

International interdependencies have long been important for economic policy, and globalization has further strengthened that relevance. This holds not only for small open economies, such as the Netherlands, but also for Europe and worldwide. This course provides basic insights based on micro foundations to better understand such interdependencies, both from a theoretical and empirical viewpoint. The course covers international trade as well as international finance.

The international trade part starts with a discussion of modern quantitative trade models, focusing on their implication for welfare in different countries as well as that of heterogeneous firms within a country. The last session then focusses on how to assess the models’ welfare implications in the data. We discuss influential empirical papers that study not only the aggregate welfare effects of trade, but that also highlight the importance of considering the distributional consequences of trade

The international finance part of the course starts from the view of the current account as a vehicle for intertemporal trade, driven by optimizing behavior of agents, which helps to analyze topics such as global imbalances and sustainability of foreign debt. We also discuss interest rate parities, floating nominal exchange rates, speculative attacks on fixed rates, sticky prices and exchange rate
volatility, quantifying pressure on the forex market for any exchange rate regime, and the relevance of exchange market pressure for central bank policy.
Students also have to write a short academic essay in which they apply a theory to a real-life event, for example.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• better understand how the interaction between any two countries is modelled in state of the art trade theories
• study tools to empirically evaluate the gains from trade, based on state of the art trade theories
• better understand the foundations of financial relations between two countries
• improve their academic writing and collaboration skills.

column1: Knowledge and understanding: Students acquire a deep understanding of the empirical implementation of so-called “new new” trade theories to evaluate the consequences of globalization. Obtaining deep understanding is also the goal of the international finance topics that are discussed.
Application of knowledge and understanding: Students apply this knowledge and understanding in a term paper. They also apply knowledge from previous courses in an international context.
Making judgements: Students apply this knowledge and understanding in a term paper, in which they also need to judge the findings of their (typically) empirical research.
Communication: Students need to write a term paper, which trains them to exchange opinions with co-authors in an efficient academic manner and to write well-structured academic texts.
Learning skills: Students acquire tools and techniques in this course, which should enable them to continue studying most current trade and international finance literature independently.

column1: <body>International environmental law (IEL) is an innovative, dynamic, and rapidly developing field that seeks to ameliorate global environmental issues such as the impacts of climate change and marine pollution/exploitation. As the causes, effects, and potential solutions of such global phenomena transcend national boundaries, international cooperation is increasingly important as reflected in a growing number of international environmental agreements governing disparate issues such as nuclear testing, hazardous substances, and atmospheric pollution. This course aims to provide students with an overview of the evolution of international environmental law, as well as an introduction to the major concepts, cases, and principles that shape effective global environmental governance. Throughout the course, attention will be focused on international responses to environmental issues with a transboundary or global scope. Following the introductory lectures, which will set the scene by introducing the major players (international institutions and actors) in the field, students will have an opportunity to explore the role of international law in regulating environmental problems such as marine pollution, climate change, nuclear testing, as well as the governance of outer space, the Arctic, and Antarctica.</body>

column1: Since the end of World War II, the international investments and other foreign activities of companies and individuals have grown substantially, and this growth is accelerating in recent decades. Firms of all types and sizes now face decisions about how to best obtain and allocate resources abroad. At the same time, significant differences in economic development between countries have persisted, and these give rise to considerable variation in the prevalence of market imperfections. Consequently, basic financial decisions now involve cross-border complexities.

This course shows how macro-level forces of trade, investment, and finance result from and, conversely, affect the micro-level actions of firms and households. In examining the key issues in international finance, we will focus on recent developments and incorporate theoretical, empirical, policy, and institutional dimensions.

The course begins with introduction describing the key trends and developments of the global economy and financial markets in the recent decades and discussing three main benefits of financial globalization: efficient investment, international risk sharing, and discipline effect on macroeconomic or corporate policies. We will also discuss one major cost of financial globalization, the sovereign debt and default.
The rest of the course is split into the two main parts: International investments and International business.

The topics covered in the International investments part include equity asset pricing in international context, foreign exchange returns, currency markets, and currency risk, international investment anomalies, and issues related international diversification of investment risk (or international risk sharing).

In the second part, we will touch upon selected issues related to the international activities at the micro (firm) level. This includes basic theory and key stylized facts about the multinational companies and selected issues related to practical international investing and international operations by the firms.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand of the mechanisms that determine the evolution of the global economic environment and its influence on domestic financial markets.

• Learn the theory of how financial globalization affect returns on investment in internationally traded equity assets and foreign exchange. Reconcile the empirical evidence with the theoretical predictions of the theoretical models.
• Describe the behavior of foreign exchange returns, putting them in the theoretical framework developed for the international asset pricing.
• Learn the patterns in the data and apply the relevant theories to explain the international capital flows and the international investment anomalies.

• Understand the reasons for emergence and examine the role of multinational firms. Learn about decisions, risks, and practical issues facing companies participating in international markets. Analyze and discuss financial problems corporations face that result from operating in an international environment.
• Using different interpretation frameworks, formulate a substantiated opinion on the scholarly and policy debate about the benefits and costs of financial globalization.
• Learn to apply the econometric techniques for empirical tests of the key theoretical relationships related to international finance.
• Collect, analyze, present, and interpret the relevant economic and financial data.
• Interpret the current economic news from the prospective of the theory and empirical research covered in the course.
• Formulate a substantiated opinion on economic national and international developments and research.

column1: This course provides an overview of the key issues in financial reporting. We use international Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as our anchor and relate the requirements for selected topics to the underlying concepts and principles. This will help you learn to make informed judgements and think critically about financial reporting problems. These are necessary skills for your future career, whether you will be preparing, auditing or using financial statements. But perhaps even more importantly, this course examines the international and political processes that shape the accounting standards and practices in Europe and the rest of the world. For every selected reporting topic, we take a step back to look at the underlying problem and critically evaluate the solution that the current standards provide.

Financial reporting is a powerful tool that influences the allocation of scarce resources across market participants. Although the IFRS Conceptual Framework identifies investors as the primary users of financial reports, we consider the economic consequences and impact on other stakeholders and society at large. The current accounting standards and practices are central to this course, but we critically discuss the limitations of financial statements. In addition to the traditional, shareholder-oriented view of financial reporting, we explore alternative views as guided by the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s). We discuss the challenges of measuring and reporting a firm’s performance and financial position, in a changing business environment. The course contributes to developing a critical mindset that helps you to address the challenges of financial reporting and your knowledge on how your decisions and actions, as a future financial manager, accountant or controller, affect investors, other stakeholders and society.

The course starts with an overview of the financial reporting environment and a short refresher of basics of the Conceptual Framework. We will continue with a selection of advanced reporting areas, including:

Attendance of the lectures and workshops is highly recommended but not mandatory. Please note that not attending workshops will affect your grade. You will still be able to take the final written test and pass the course. There are no compensatory assignments.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Demonstrate an understanding of the international, institutional environment of financial reporting, its limitations and challenges
• Apply and discuss the main provisions and criteria of the accounting standards covered in this course
• Use underlying principles and concepts to critically evaluate financial reporting decisions
• Make informed judgements for financial reporting issues in the problem areas that are covered in this course
• Compile financial statement items from fact patterns compliant with the standards covered in this course
• Critically evaluate the current state of financial reporting and challenges of alternative perspectives on integrated reporting

column1: <body>How can we use international law to protect and promote human health? This course focuses on the impact of international treaty law on health care systems and protecting human rights in healthcare. The course starts with identifying the underlying principles of health law. These principles provide the framework for regulatory intervention in     the field of healthcare. The rationale for such intervention includes protecting and promoting good health, and ensuring appropriate and equitable access to healthcare of good quality. Good health raises questions about access to medical care in the context of scarcity of resources, the right to health, patients’ rights, and protection of vulnerable groups. These questions are influenced by legal standards as defined in international treaty law and interpreted in the case law of international courts and treaty bodies.</body>

column1: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Identify international law sources on human rights in health and healthcare
• Analyze the case law of international human rights courts and treaty bodies on enforcing rights in healthcare
• Analyze contemporary legal problems and dilemmas pertaining to the health-related rights of vulnerable groups
• Formulate relevant legal arguments in the patients’ rights debate
• Apply the relevant international human rights instruments and case law to case scenarios involving applicants who want to enforce their health rights

column1: The purpose of this course is to add a human rights dimension to the overall health law program of the ESL-master Recht van de gezondheidszorg. Students will be introduced to the human rights framework with a view to enable them to conceptualize issues from a human rights perspective. A substantial portion of the course will then be spent on exploring the Right to Health through various regional and international mechanisms. After having considered health and human rights protection of so-called vulnerable groups (i.e. children, women, prisoners) in some detail, the focus finally shifts towards human rights case law. Since human rights protection is organized at various levels, attention is paid to United Nations human rights law as well as to human rights law as developed by the Council of Europe.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The student obtains a thorough understanding of international human rights law relating to health issues.
• The student acquires knowledge of international human rights law relating to health issues as developed within the contexts of the United Nations and the Council of Europe.
• The student is able to apply his newly acquired knowledge and understanding of international health law, implying that:
• he is able to recognize the relevant human rights aspects of a case;
• he is able to apply relevant human rights law to a case;
• he can come up with a logical answer to legal questions arising out of a case, by applying relevant human rights law.
• The student demonstrates a critical attitude during lectures and seminars.
• The student is able to express himself adequately in English, verbally as well as in writing.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course adopts a holistic approach to learning international human rights law, beginning from its normative foundations and emergence as a distinct field of international law to its contemporary status and challenges for the future. Given the introductory nature of this course, emphasis is placed throughout on idealism as well as realism, including an understanding of how international and domestic politics have influenced and continue to influence the field of international human rights law. On the normative side, participants will analyses the merits and demerits of categorizing human rights under different labels and its effects on human rights promotion. They will look at case studies from around the world that expose the tensions between cultural relativism and universality of human rights, and will also look at the concepts of collective rights and rights of vulnerable persons. On the practical side, participants will be introduced to the most important mechanisms as well as challenges to the realisation and promotion of human rights, including State compliance and judicial enforcement. Finally, the inter-play between nation-states and civil society will be scrutinised with a strong focus on NGO activism and the emerging challenges thereto.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In recent years, the media industries have undergone profound transformations due to the emergence of new digital technologies and distribution platforms such as gaming, the internet, and mobile platforms. These changes have had a significant impact on the operations of companies, workers, and policymakers within the media industries. Market boundaries that were once distinct have converged, novel media products and business models have been developed, and users have transitioned from passive consumers to active contributors in content creation through user-generated content. This period of apparent chaos and upheaval in the media industries sets the foundation for this course.

Throughout this course, students will delve into the latest trends and advancements in the media industries. We will begin by establishing the theoretical foundations that are essential for comprehending and researching media industries and media innovation. Subsequently, our focus will shift towards exploring the trends within the media industries and analyzing how these trends influence the strategic behavior of various industry stakeholders such as companies, audiences, and policymakers. In addition to examining relevant literature, we will incorporate guest lectures and online materials, including videos, to facilitate discussions on the current trends and strategies within the dynamic media sector.

• What international journalists are, and what international and global journalism involves
• How and why journalistic practices and international news coverage vary across different contexts
• Analyze, compare and critically reflect upon journalistic practices using concepts and theories covered in this course

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is about international law and how it can be used to tackle international social challenges, such as conflicts or climate change.

International law can be conceived as a specific kind of rules. In the national legal setting, there are authorities making law and judges bound to the application and interpretation of existing law when judging. However, in the international law, almost all legal power needs to be voluntarily accepted by states. That creates unique challenges for using law to address the most pressing rules. However, similarly to domestic law, international law is about formulating and interpreting social norms. As such it contributes to creating and upholding social order. Hence, the law and the state are inextricably linked.

At the domestic level, the law pertains to the rights and duties that individuals have vis a vis each other as well as those between states and individuals. The rules regulating contacts within the society of states are generally called international law. One of the aims of international law is to address cross border societal problems in a peaceful way. Traditionally international law is based on national sovereignty which means that there is no authority above states. However, over time states have empowered non-state actors with supranational (or intergovernmental) authorities such as the international organizations that are part of the UN family. This development has fundamentally changed international law as it means that states have surrendered some of their sovereignty to these international organizations. Consequently, modern international law includes also other actors than states, such as international organizations, private actors and even citizens.

The first part of this course deals with the basics of law in modern society. It addresses questions such as: what is law, where can it be found, how is it organized into different domains, and how is it related to the state? It also shows the development and evolution of international law, including its sources, subjects, and institutions.

The second part of the course focuses on the application of international law to the main international challenges today – war, environment, and technology. In this part, we will focus on how international law enables – but also hampers – the development of effective frameworks to deal with international social challenges. Today, addressing such challenges requires bringing in a broader set of actors, and new forms of institutions.

The conceptual focus of law and regulation is illustrated with the handling of cross-national social problems, spurred on by a globalizing economy. The first part of the course aims at answering corresponding questions with a comprehensive introduction in the study of international law. The second part of the course reflects on the changing role of international law in addressing today’s main challenges in international law.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:
1. reproduce the basic concepts of law in modern society;
2. place conflicts, questions and issues in the different fields of law;
3. describe the most important changes in the relationship between law and states during recent history;
4. explain the basics of international law including its most important sources, subjects, and institutions;
5. explain how international law affects different social challenges.

column1: Moot court is a simulation of a fictional dispute between countries before the International Courts. Students prepare oral and written pleadings arguing both the applicant and respondent positions of the case. The students analyze the problem, identify the legal issues, research the law, write the briefs and orally present in front of an international tribunal, like the real-life lawyers do.

A team of EUC students will participate in Telders International Law Moot Court Competition, which is organized by Leiden University. Each year student teams are presented with a case involving a fictitious dispute between two States, which is brought before the International Court of Justice (ICJ). It is up to the teams to defend the two States to the best of their abilities.

In Telders International Law Moot Court Competition the students' written and oral argumentations are judged by legal experts such as judges from the ICJ(Telders' Final in the Peace Palace), other international courts, delegates from the International Committee of the Red Cross and professors of law guaranteeing high intellectual standards and the prestige of these Competitions. Therefore, participation in these Moot Courts is a strong asset especially for the students who wish to do a Masters Degree in International Law.

Throughout four quads, weekly meetings will be held (contact hours 2-3 hours per week), readings will be assigned, and student preparation is expected at individual and group level. The students will be closely supervised by the coaches. The deadlines for the assessments will be known provided once the competition cases and timelines will bear published. Please keep in mind that these deadlines might fall within the Winter Break, which could mean that some work would be required during the breaks.

column1: <body>Dit vak verschaft een inleiding in internationale migratie en diverse gerelateerde verschijnselen. Het vak belicht zowel de oorzaken van internationale migratie als de gevolgen van internationale migratie voor de zendende en de ontvangende samenlevingen. We bespreken diverse economische en sociologische theorieën die verklaren waarom mensen vanuit het ene naar een ander land migreren, vaak van het ene naar een ander deel van de wereld. Een tweede centraal thema in het vak betreft de gevolgen van migratie voor de herkomstlanden en –gemeenschappen. Wat zijn economische en sociale ontwikkelingen in de herkomstgemeenschappen als gevolg van migratie? En wat zijn de gevolgen voor de ontvangende samenlevingen op het gebied van sociaaleconomische (of structurele) integratie en sociaal-culturele integratie (of “assimilatie”). Hoe kan de sterke culturele diversiteit in de gemeenschappen waar veel migranten zich vestigen begrepen worden? En hoe reageren de oorspronkelijke bewoners van deze gemeenschappen hierop? Al dit soort vragen staan centraal in dit vak.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na afronding van dit vak heeft de student:

column2: • Inzicht in de omvang en het karakter van internationale migratieprocessen in verschillende delen van de wereld, zowel in het heden als het verleden;
• Goed begrip van economische en sociologische theorieën die bijdragen aan de opkomst, continuering en eventueel afname van internationale migratieprocessen;
• Begrijpen in welke mate en hoe migratiebeleid en migratie controle van ontvangende samenlevingen internationale migratiestromen kunnen sturen;

• Begrijpen en een onderbouwd standpunt kunnen innemen of internationale migratie al dan niet, en onder welke voorwaarden, bijdraagt aan de economische ontwikkeling van en sociale verhoudingen in herkomstgemeenschappen;
• Begrijpen en een onderbouwd standpunt kunnen innemen of migranten (eerste en tweede generatie) al dan niet, en onder welke voorwaarden, een plek vinden in de ontvangende samenleving;
• Beleidsopties en -aanbevelingen kunnen ontwikkelen en formuleren omtrent actuele thema’s gelieerd aan internationale migratie en de integratie van migranten.

column1: There were more than 281 million migrants in the world in 2021 according to the World Migration report from the International Organization for Migration (IOM). This is more than the total population of many developed countries. Accordingly, the regulation of migration, its political and economic causes and consequences, and attitudes toward migration shape the partisan debate in many developed and developing countries. Especially, the rise of anti-immigration populist parties in Europe, the Brexit vote, and the election of Donald Trump in 2016 and his term as the U.S. president brought an additional emphasis to the study of the topic.

This course gives an overview of existing migration theories and explores the political, social, and economic causes and consequences of migration from three perspectives: (a) from the perspective of receiving countries, (b) from the perspective of migrants themselves, and (c) from the perspective of sending countries. For receiving countries, the most pressing issues are the regulation of migration (i.e., how, when, and how many migrants to receive), attitudes and potential opposition to migration in the current contexts, and solidarity and support for social policy in the receiving countries. Secondly, migrants themselves face various hindrances before, during and after migration. related to social, economic, and cultural integration in the receiving societies. Finally, the course studies the impact of migration on political stability, brain drain, democracy, development, and remittances in the sending countries.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

Build a solid understanding of prominent causes and consequences of migration from the perspectives of sending and receiving countries and communities, as well as migrants themselves using an interdisciplinary approach (sociology, political sciences, law, economics);
Be able to critique the methodological as well as theoretical assumptions, conclusions, and arguments in the field of migration studies and summarize information in a concise policy brief;
Be able to design, conduct and analyze qualitative research methods and apply ethical standards in research with vulnerable groups in society;
Engage with and use scientific arguments to take a substantiated position on migration, migrant integration, and the management of migration.

column1: This course assesses historical developments in the global world economy with a particular emphasis on the role of international institutions such as the WTO, the IMF and the World Bank. It applies political economy theories to explain and evaluate the need for global cooperation in the areas of trade, finance, poverty reduction and the environment. It deals with the internal governance structure of global economic institutions as well as their effectiveness. The course explicitly includes the perspectives of developing countries, both in discussing the consequences of economic globalization and in discussing the effectiveness of international economic institutions and regimes. In addition, the effectiveness of foreign aid is discussed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After the course, students are able to:
• Assess the nature of economic globalization and its consequences, in particular for developing countries
• Evaluate the need for global public goods in the areas of trade, finance, poverty and the environment

• Evaluate the decision making procedures of the major existing global economic institutions and regimes, such as the WTO, the IMF, the OECD, the World Bank and the (UN) Framework Convention on Climate Change, as well as international NGOs
• Assess the effectiveness of these global economic institutions both in general and for developing countries in particular
• Analyse data from international databases to answer simple but relevant empirical questions.

column1: This course will be significantly different than any other course you have ever taken. Its design is such that it has features of both a course and a competitive consulting assignment. The selective covers many aspects of branding, marketing and communications in a challenging way. L’Oréal is offering the marketing students of Erasmus University a unique opportunity to play the role of consultant, and dive into a very dynamic, real-life, practical assignment. At the same time, the selective is designed such that teams will be able to make well-underpinned marketing plans by applying the right concepts, methods and techniques.

It provides the opportunity to develop marketing and consulting skills through a practical, real-life experience, the chance to work closely with professionals in their field, and the possibility of winning a contest at one of several levels. All of these can contribute to one’s clarification of what kind of professional career could be interesting to pursue (or not) in the future. Being able to discuss the experience and what was learned with future employers. The course as it is designed, is a lot of work, and a lot of fun.

The 2024 year’s theme will revolve around Professional Products Division and Digitilization/E-commere/AI. This assignment is a mix of branding, design thinking, marketing communications, service innovation and digital strategy.
Course attendance rules. For all course elements presence is mandatory. But flexibility is possible when there are good reasons.

column1: In the past decades governments all over the world, including at the international level, have been involved in various waves of reform of the public sector and organizations therein. Different labels are  in use to describe these reforms, such as New Public Management, New Public Governance, and Whole of Governance. In this course you will become acquainted with these reforms in different countries, their trajectory and results. Examples will come from organizational reforms such as the large scale creation of semi-autonomous agencies, to reforms of financial and HR management.

The impact of these reforms and the financial crisis on the public sector in various countries is highly disputed. Some authors claim there is a trend towards convergence, making all public sectors become alike, while other authors point to the trade-offs and paradoxes between the strive for more efficiency and quality at the same time. Precise results are difficult to ascertain because of a lack of evaluation studies but it is clear that not all reforms have been beneficial.
In this course students will also investigate an example of a reform in a country outside of the Netherlands, to explain the causes and consequences of that reform.

This course is part of the Master in International Public Management and Public Policy (IMP) and also available as an elective course for students from other Master programmes in Public Administration. Please notice that the eligibility criteria for the IMP programme are higher than for the Dutch Master programmes, both in terms of English proficiency (which is higher than the level achieved in Dutch secondary schools) and in terms of grades obtained in the Bachelor programme. This course is geared towards this higher level. Students from other programmes are strongly recommended to take note of these admission criteria for the IMP Master, see www.imp.eur.nl

column1: This EUR minor offered by EUC will examine unresolved practical, theoretical and legal questions concerning the issues of international relations as well as universality of human rights; whose responsibility it is to protect human rights; and whether human rights conventions, laws and regimes are effective. Thus, the course looks at the juxtaposition of the traditional claims of states to guard sovereignty and impose order against more recent claims by individuals to freedom, rights, justice, universal moral order and humane treatment. State sovereignty and international relations have a profound impact on the ability of the international community to respond to gross human rights violations. Thus, the positive and negative impacts of domestic politics and transnational actors and the collision of human rights ideals with the doctrine of state sovereignty will be recurring themes in the course.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: 1)      Understanding the theories and issues of International Relations
2)      Understanding foundational values and basic doctrines of fundamental rights, being able to apply the latter in concrete cases

3)      Understanding the interaction between sovereignty concerns for states with ‘legitimacy concerns’ of international courts, and being able to identify the tension with the effective protection of fundamental rights.
4)      Understanding the role of interpretation principles characteristic of human rights in this regard.

column1: This course provides a critical introduction to International Relations (IR) Theory for historians. It seeks to develop the analytical tools required for theoretically informed historical research into IR. We begin with two crucial philosophical (epistemological and ontological) questions: what is, or should be, the relationship between History and IR Theory? What ‘is’ theory, and what does it ‘do’ for us as researchers? The module introduces all important current IR theories including dominant traditional theories (such as constructivism, realism and  liberalism) that explain contemporary international politics, as well as critical theories (such as feminism, green theory, and  postcolonialism) that challenge traditional realist and liberal thought. In weekly assignments, student reflect upon the use and abuse of theory, while in the final part students apply their theory of choice to a case study of their choice in global history. Mastery of IR theory will prove not only helpful in writing the final paper and the MA thesis, but also helps students gain a much deeper understanding of foreign affairs and international politics, both in the recent past and in the twenty-first century.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can analyse major theories of international relations
• Students can evaluate the relationship between theory and history in International Relations
• Students can successfully apply an IR theory to produce a theoretically informed historical case study of a subject in global history

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114734,2023,International Relations and the Sea,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. EM Jacobs', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Relations across the sea are inherently international. People from all over the world use the sea for trade and transport, to exchange ideas, to wage wars or to make a profit. These relations have many dimensions, all of which can be chosen as approaches for thesis research, whether from an economic, social, military, cultural, technical or political perspective.

By drawing on the collection of the Maritime Museum Rotterdam, the International Relations and the Sea RWS is unique in integrating the analysis of written sources with the study of artefacts. Students will have the rare opportunity to participate in scientific research contributing to museum activities, exhibitions and publications through internships related to their thesis topic. As this RWS is directly connected with the Maritime Museum where students can do their (extended) internship, it is especially suitable for students Applied History.

The International Relations and the Sea RWS makes it possible to tackle many different dimensions and dynamics. Topics focus on the historic spaces where people from all over the world connect and where maritime connections provide an important impetus for societal change. Many dynamics in port cities can be explained by changes in global maritime history.

As early as the 19th century, the introduction of steam power and the electronic telegraph made the world a smaller place. The transfer of goods, persons and information accelerated, enhancing interconnectedness between people of different nations and cultures. After a period of rising nationalism and more inward-looking economic policies, in which the sea became a battlefield – too often ignored in the history of the wars –  the post-war years experienced another wave of increasing globalization. Maritime interconnectedness spurred globalization and transformed society on many levels. At the same time the exploration of the resources of the seas resulted in new borders and border conflicts, from the British-Islandic Cod-wars (1950s-1970s) to the recent conflicts about grain deals between Russia and Ukraine.

In the RWS International Relations and the Sea, students learn how to structure and conduct historical research adequately and efficiently. The tutorial classes (on location in the Maritime Museum Rotterdam) focus on the critical assessment of the research methodology and data collection. In addition, much consideration will be given to the analysis, reporting, and presentation of research findings.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report, and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

column1: The aim of this introductory course on international relations theory is to familiarise you with the concepts, ideas and analytical tools necessary to understand state behaviour and relationships between various actors in the international system. Competing analytical perspectives explaining state behaviour such as realism, liberalism and constructivism will be examined. The course will also examine alternative approaches to international relations such as Marxism, feminism, post-colonialism, post-structuralism, and Green theory. Each of these frameworks will be applied to different case studies to explore how the theory works in practice. By the end of the course you will have knowledge of international relations theory and are able to analyse a myriad of issues in global affairs from a variety of perspectives.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Students will understand how major scholars have theorized international relations; assess contributions and short-comings of both mainstream and alternative theories; enhance their analytical skills and develop capacity to engage in complex political issues; demonstrate how theory provides a road map by which to examine international events and processes.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: International society is a complex structure where states, domestic and transnational actors and interest groups, and international institutions interact with one another influencing domestic and international politics and policies. This course discusses the implications of this interaction in terms of democratic institutions both at the global and domestic levels.

The course consists of two main parts. The first part introduces the institutional building blocks of democracy and surveys four distinct take on the debates on the possibility of democracy at the global level. Specifically, the course starts with a discussion on whether international institutions can ever be democratic. Here it surveys four contradicting viewpoints: sovereigntist accounts (that are pessimistic about building accountable and representative international institutions), liberals (who are optimistic that international organizations can be democratic), globalists (who propose the ideal of a ‘cosmopolitan/world democracy’), and populists (who challenge international organization on the basis of a split between ‘global elites’ and ‘real people’).

The second part of the course looks at how international society can influence the transition to democracy and the functioning of democratic government at the domestic level. It discusses the international influence on domestic democratic institutions and actors. It looks at whether and when international society can promote democracy at home. It explores anti-globalization protest movements and bottom-up contestation against international institutions. It concludes with a discussion on how current challenges are catalysed in the discussion of the legitimacy of international institutions, multilateral world order and future of democracy at global and national levels.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of this course, students

column2: • Will gain a solid understanding of democratic institutions and norms and their reflections at the global and domestic levels;

• will be able to identify and critically reflect on the interaction between international organisations, nation-states, and domestic and transnational actors interests, and their implications in terms of democratic institutions;
• will have developed a capacity for empirical and normative discussion on the possibility and likelihood of a ‘global democracy’ and democratizing global governance structures;
• will be able to assess the impact of international institutions on domestic democratic institutions;
• will be able to report their own research in a coherently written short piece of academic writing and a seminar presentation.

column1: Why do countries trade? Is everyone better off from trade? Why and how do governments use trade policy instruments and how do they affect the economy? What is the role of the WTO and what can explain the proliferation of trade agreements? These are some of the questions we will explore in this course. We will begin by reviewing the traditional trade models of Ricardo and Hecksher-Ohlin, and identify the winners and losers from trade. Then we will study the instruments of trade policy and their effects. The course will then move to the political economy of trade policy to understand what determines trade policy, and we will conclude by studying the world trading system, paying special attention to the role of the WTO and regional trade agreements.
The following topics will be covered during this course:
1. Introduction to Trade and Trade Policy
4. Trade Policy Instruments and their effects
6. Multilateral Trade Negotiations and the Rise of FTAs

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To understand the economics of international trade and its distributional consequences.
• To learn about the most frequently used trade policy instruments and their effects.
• To understand the role of the WTO and regional trade agreements in the world trading system.
• To quantify the effects of policy actions on different groups in a country.
• To acquire mathematical skills in formalizing economic models.

column1: <body>This course introduces students to the core themes in international communication studies. The course pays special attention to the historical, politico-economic, social, cultural, and technological factors that have shaped both (1) communication relations across the globe and (2) the way in which we think about these relations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The key developments in international communication and international communication research since the mid-20th century;
• The different factors that affect communication flows across the globe;
• The relevance of paying attention to local contexts of production and consumption in order to study global media processes;
• New technologies'  challenges and opportunities for international communication.
• Analyze and critically reflect upon existing international communication research;
• Apply key concepts from the course to the study and assessment of local, national, transnational, and supranational communication  processes;
• Engage in an informed and critical way in pressing contemporary debates, such as those related to the world information society and to communication rights;
• Work in international and intercultural groups to assess issues related to international communication.
